(Mathematics) (True/False Statements, Multi-part) D 2 (With Illustration)

Look at these statements about fact families. Write true or false next to each statement and give at least three examples to show that your answer is correct. The first one has been done for you.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item A fact family consists of a group of related addition and subtraction or multiplication and division facts.
\item In a fact family involving the numbers 2, 3, and 5, the equations are 2 + 3 = 5 and 5 - 3 = 2.
\item Every fact family has exactly four equations.
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Bethan and Riley collect 240 pebbles from the beach. They share them equally into four piles. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many pebbles are there in each pile?
\item What is the fraction of pebbles in each pile compared to the total number of pebbles?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A beach scene with 240 pebbles divided into four equal piles. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Sanjit buys 56 cakes. He shares them equally onto eight plates. How many cakes are there on each plate? What is the fraction of cakes on each plate?

\subsection{Answers}
There are 7 cakes on each plate, and the fraction is \( \frac{7}{1} \).

[STRDGM] A visual representation of 8 plates, each with 7 cakes arranged neatly. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Ahmed has \$48.50. He puts the money equally into two bags. How much money is in each bag? What is the fraction you found?

\subsection{Answers}
Each bag contains \$24.25, and the fraction is \( \frac{1}{2} \).

[STRDGM] A stack of money and coins arranged in two bags, each labeled with the amount of money inside. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Antonio buys 35 chocolate bars. He shares them between five people. How many chocolate bars does each person get? What is the fraction you found?

\subsection{Answers}
Each person gets 7 chocolate bars, and the fraction is \(\frac{7}{35}\) or \(\frac{1}{5}\).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Shelly organizes 138 beads into six piles. How many beads are in each pile? What is the fraction of beads in each pile?

\subsection{Answers}
Each pile contains 23 beads, and the fraction is \(\frac{23}{138}\).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Ashley puts tins of beans in boxes. He has 125 tins. There are 8 tins in each box. How many boxes does he need? Did you round your answer up or down? Why?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many boxes does Ashley need?
\item Did you round your answer up or down? Why?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of 125 tins of beans being divided into boxes, with each box containing 8 tins. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Beverly has a box of 120 books. She puts them on shelves, placing 7 books on each shelf. How many shelves does she use? Did you round your answer up or down? Why?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the number of shelves used.
\item Explain whether you rounded your answer up or down and provide the reasoning.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A stack of books arranged on shelves, with 7 books on each shelf and a total of 120 books. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Manni has 146 potatoes. He puts them in bags of eight. How many bags does he fill? Did you round your answer up or down? Why?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many bags does Manni fill?
\item Did you round your answer up or down? Why?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of 146 whole potatoes being placed into bags, with each bag containing 8 potatoes. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Rachel makes bracelets. She has 218 beads. She puts 8 beads on each bracelet. How many bracelets can she make? Did you round your answer up or down? Why?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many bracelets can Rachel make?
\item Did you round your answer up or down? Why?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A bracelet made of colorful beads laid out on a table, with 2 extra beads scattered around. [STPDGM]

Think: How many more to make 45? Count up from 27 to 45, the missing number is 18.

[STRDGM] A number line showing increments from 27 to 45, with the number 18 highlighted as the difference. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Missing Numbers Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (Multi-part)

Find the missing numbers.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 15 + \_\_\_ = 34 \)
\item \( \_\_\_ + 100 = 86 \)
\item \( \_\_\_ + 34 = 67 \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A series of equations with blank spaces for missing numbers, arranged in a list format. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Balance Scales Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Make these scales balance.

\begin{equation*}
28 + \_\_\_ = 20 - 16
\end{equation*}

\begin{equation*}
27 + \_\_\_ = 15 + 12
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] Two balance scales, one side showing \(28 + \_\_\_\) and the other side showing \(20 - 16\) for the first scale. The second scale shows \(27 + \_\_\_\) on one side and \(15 + 12\) on the other side. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (True or False Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Write true or false next to each sentence.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( q + 14 = 14 + q \)
\item \( 23 + 25 = 52 + 42 \)
\item \( 68 - 31 = 23 - 14 \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A list of equations with space for answers labeled "true" or "false" next to each equation. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration)

Draw a line to match the improper fraction with the equivalent mixed number.

[STRDGM] A grid with the following improper fractions: \( \frac{9}{4}, \frac{7}{3}, \frac{5}{2} \) and the following mixed numbers: \( 2\frac{1}{4}, 2\frac{1}{3}, 2\frac{1}{2} \) scattered throughout. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Number Rounding Exercise, Multi-part) D 5 (With Illustration)

Pick four digit cards and write them in the table. Make a number with two decimal places and write it in the table. Round your number to the nearest whole number. Then round your number to the nearest tenth. Write your answers in the table. Use the same cards to make a second number and write it in the table. Round your number to the nearest whole number. Then round your number to the nearest tenth. Write your answers in the table. Compare your two numbers using \( > \) or \( < \). An example is shown in the table. How many numbers can you make and round in the time allowed?

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Digits} & \textbf{First Number} & \textbf{Rounded to Nearest Whole Number} & \textbf{Second Number} & \textbf{Rounded to Nearest Whole Number} & \textbf{Comparison} \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

[STRDGM] A situational table with columns for digits, first number, rounded to nearest whole number, second number, rounded to nearest whole number, and comparison. [STPDGM]

Use four digit cards to make numbers with two decimal places. Choose for your numbers to be quantities of metres, kilograms, or litres. Use a mixture of them all as you work through the activity. Put your numbers and amounts in the table below. Complete the rest of the table by rounding, following the instructions. An example is shown for you.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Numbers Picked} & \textbf{Amount Made} & \textbf{Round to the Nearest Tenth} & \textbf{Round to the Nearest Whole Number} \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\item 73 - 37 = 36  
\item 82 - 28 = __  
\end{enumerate}

   What is the best 3D shape to use for the balance beam?

3. Design a hopscotch game.  
   Use at least three different 2D shapes.

   Think about how to make the swings stable.  
   What angles will you use?  

5. Draw a sketch of the playground to illustrate your results.

(Mathematics) (Area Calculation, Word Problem) D 4 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

How many square centimeters are in a square meter? Find the area of each shape in square centimeters and draw a different shape with the same area.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many square centimeters are in a square meter?
\item Calculate the area of the following shapes in square centimeters: 
\begin{itemize}
    \item A rectangle measuring 10 cm by 5 cm.
    \item A triangle with a base of 6 cm and a height of 4 cm.
    \item A circle with a radius of 3 cm.
\end{itemize}
\item Draw a different shape that has the same area as the rectangle you calculated.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid with various shapes filled in different colors, with spaces for area calculations and drawing new shapes. [STPDGM]

1. Draw as many different rectangles with a perimeter of 20 cm as you can.  
   Work out the area (the number of squares) for each one.  
   Write the areas here: __________________________________  
   How many did you find? ________________________________  
   Do you think that you have found them all? _______________  
   Check your findings with another pair of students.  

2. Draw as many different rectangles with an area of 24 square cm as you can.  
   Work out the perimeter of each one.  
   Write the perimeters here: ____________________________  
   How many did you find? ________________________________  
   Do you think that you have found them all? _______________  
   Check your findings with another pair of students.  

3. Measure the perimeter of three rectangular objects in your classroom.  
   For example: your book or your desk.  
   \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
   \hline
   Object & Length (cm) & Width (cm) & Perimeter (cm) \\
   \hline
   & & & \\
   \hline
   & & & \\
   \hline
   & & & \\
   \hline
   \end{tabular}

[STRDGM] A grid layout with squares for drawing rectangles and spaces for writing areas, perimeters, and object measurements. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Measuring Exercise, Word Problem) D 4 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

1. Measure the edges of these rectangles and calculate the perimeter:  
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item The perimeter is __________ cm.  
   \item The perimeter is __________ cm.  
   \item The perimeter is __________ cm.  
   \item The perimeter is __________ cm.  
   \end{enumerate}

2. Floor tiles cost \$25 per square metre.  
   How much does it cost to tile these rooms?  
   Draw a floor plan for each one.  
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item Room 1 is 5 m long and 3 m wide. Cost: __________  
   \item Room 2 is 4 m square. Cost: __________  
   \item Room 3 is 4 m long and 2.5 m wide. Cost: __________  
   \end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Rectangles with dimensions for measuring and calculating costs, with spaces for costs next to each room. [STPDGM]

\item What is the largest possible total you can get from pulling numbers out of the bag?
\item What is the smallest possible total you can get from pulling numbers out of the bag?
\item Did you find any quick ways to add numbers together?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Card Number Difference Exercise, Word Problem) D 3 (With Illustration)

(Mathematics) (Partner Activity, Game) D 5 (With Illustration)

Work with a partner and two sets of digit cards. Shuffle the cards and place them face down on the table in front of you. Take turns to pick a number. Choose where to place your digit in the table. Write the number it represents in the correct place in the table. Continue until you have made a 6-digit number. Write your 6-digit number in the last column. Rearrange them to make the largest number possible. Each time your number is larger than your partner’s number, you score a point. The player with the highest score is the winner.

[STRDGM] A table with columns labeled 100,000, 10,000, 1,000, 100, 10, 1, and a column for the final number. There are eight rows for players to fill in their digits. [STPDGM]

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{First Number} & \textbf{Result} \\
\hline

(Mathematics) (Graphing Exercise, Estimation Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

On squared paper, draw a line graph to show the following temperature data over a 12-hour period:

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Time} & \textbf{Temperature (°C)} \\
\hline
12:15 & 15 \\
13:15 & 18 \\
17:45 & 22 \\
19:30 & 20 \\
19:45 & 21 \\
22:30 & 16 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the mode of the temperature data?
\item Estimate what the temperature was at the following times:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
  \item 19:30
  \item 13:15
  \item 17:45
  \item 22:30
  \item 12:15
  \item 19:45
  \end{enumerate}
\item Now make up some questions to ask the class.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A line graph showing temperature data over a 12-hour period, with time on the x-axis and temperature in degrees Celsius on the y-axis. The graph features points connected by lines, indicating temperature changes throughout the day. [STPDGM]

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item What is the temperature at 14:00?
\item What is the temperature at 17:30?
\item George wants to go for a run during the two coolest hours of the day. When is the best time?
\item Daisy likes to be outside during the hottest part of the day. Which four hours are best?
\item What is the mode temperature?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A temperature graph showing the temperature over a 24-hour period with clear markings for each hour. [STPDGM]

\item For the ratio of blue to yellow as \( 1:6 \), how many tins of paint A and B do you need?
\end{enumerate}

[STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

a) How much fruit juice do I need for six people?

b) How much water do I use for 150 millilitres of fruit juice?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What two numbers do you need to roll to make 10? I + __________ = 10.
\item 4 + __________ = 10. 
\item Find some more combinations that add up to 10.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Rashid had a number. He multiplied his number by 10 and got 134. What was his original number?

\subsection{Answers}
The original number is 13.4.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (Multi-part)

Naomi had a tray of 12 eggs. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many eggs are there in 100 identical trays?
\item If Naomi uses 24 eggs, how many eggs will be left in the trays?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Courtney collected 10¢ coins. She had $11 of 10¢ coins. How many 10¢ coins did she have?

\subsection{Answers}
Courtney had 110 coins.

(Mathematics) (Ratio and Proportion, Ingredient Calculation) D 5 (Multi-part)

These are the ingredients needed for a fruit salad. It serves 4 people.  

\begin{itemize}
    \item 2 apples  
    \item 3 peaches  
    \item 4 bananas  
    \item 5 kiwi fruit  
    \item 1 litre orange juice  
\end{itemize}

The ratio of apples to peaches is \( 2:3 \).  

What is the ratio of:  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
    \item Apples to bananas?  
    \item Peaches to kiwi fruit?  
    \item Apples to kiwi fruit?  
    \item Peaches to bananas?  
    \item All of the fruit used?  
\end{enumerate}

- Rewrite the ingredients needed to serve 8 people:  

- Now rewrite the ingredients needed to serve 2 people:  

- Use what you know to write the ingredients needed to serve 10 people:  

[STRDGM] A table with ingredients and their quantities, labeled for clarity. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Drawing and Ratio Identification, Word Problem) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Hope has 8 bars of chocolate.  
\(\frac{3}{8}\) are dark chocolate. The other bars are white chocolate.  
What is the ratio of dark to white chocolate?  
- Draw a picture to show this.  
- Write the ratio beside your picture.  

Grace has 20 hair braids.  
\(\frac{3}{4}\) of the hair braid beads are red. The other hair braid beads are blue.  
What is the ratio of red to blue hair braid beads?  
- Draw a picture to show this.  
- Write the ratio beside your picture.  

Shafi has 15 animals on his farm.  
\(\frac{2}{5}\) of the animals are chicken. The other animals are sheep.  
What is the ratio of chicken to sheep?  
- Draw a picture to show this.  
- Write the ratio beside your picture.  

Dom has 24 counters.  
\(\frac{1}{3}\) of the counters are blue, \(\frac{1}{2}\) are red. The other counters are yellow.  
What is the ratio of blue, red, and yellow counters?  
- Draw a picture to show this.  
- Write the ratio beside your picture.  

[STRDGM] Various drawings of chocolate bars, hair braids, animals, and counters, each labeled to indicate the colors or types. [STPDGM]

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]

\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Clock Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 1 (With Illustration)

It is always an o'clock time. What number should the long hand point to? ________ Turn the long hand to that number. Make some more o'clock times. I have made ________ o'clock. Draw the hands.

[STRDGM] Two clock faces are shown. The first clock has the hour hand pointing slightly past the 1 and the minute hand pointing at the 12. The second clock is blank with numbers from 1 to 12 around the edge. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Classification Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

Draw or write the fruit and other items in their new boxes.

[STRDGM] A grid with two rows and two columns labeled "Red" and "Not Red" on the top, and "Fruit" and "Not Fruit" on the side. The grid contains images of an apple and a strawberry in the "Red Fruit" section, a banana in the "Not Red Fruit" section, a cabbage and radish in the "Not Red" section, and a cherry in the "Red Not Fruit" section. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Counting Exercise, Multi-part) D 1 (With Answer)

How many red fruits? There are __________ red fruits.

How many red items which are not fruit? There are __________ red items which are not fruit.

How many red items altogether? There are __________ red items altogether.

How many items are there that are not red? __________

\subsection{Answers}
1. Number of red fruits: [Your answer here]
2. Number of red items which are not fruit: [Your answer here]
3. Total number of red items: [Your answer here]
4. Number of items that are not red: [Your answer here]


(Mathematics) (Table Completion, Word Problem) D 4 (With Illustration)

Use this '100 cents square' to help you complete the table:

- Write each fraction as a number of cents and in dollars.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Fraction} & \textbf{Cents} & \textbf{Dollars} \\
\hline
\frac{1}{4} & 25 & 0.25 \\
\hline
\frac{1}{2} & 50 & 0.50 \\
\hline
\frac{3}{4} & 75 & 0.75 \\
\hline
1 & 100 & 1.00 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

[STRDGM] A grid filled with 100 small circles, each representing 1 cent, arranged in rows and columns. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Problem Solving, Word Problem) D 4 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

You have a bag of money containing dollar notes (\$1), quarters (25¢), and cents (¢). You can only take 5 coins or notes out of the bag. What different amounts can you make? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the smallest possible amount? __________
\item What is the largest possible amount? __________
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] An illustration of a bag filled with various coins and notes, showing a mix of denominations including at least one dollar note, several quarters, and various cents. [STPDGM]

\item 178 cm = __________ m
\item 380 cm = __________ m
\item 432 cm = __________ m
\item 10 cm = __________ m
\item 502 cm = __________ m
\end{enumerate}

How much is in each purse? Write your answer in dollars.

1. The first purse contains 3 quarters, 2 dimes, and 1 nickel. 
2. The second purse contains 2 one-dollar bills and 3 pennies. 
3. The third purse contains 1 five-dollar bill and 1 quarter. 
Each purse has a line for writing the total amount. 
[STPDGM]

\item 0.4 = \(\frac{2}{5}\)
\item 0.3 = \(\frac{1}{3}\)
\item 0.75 = \(\frac{3}{4}\)
\item 0.25 = \(\frac{1}{4}\)
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Time Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration)

Fill in the times for your daily schedule:

I get up at: __________  

I have breakfast at: __________  

I arrive at school at: __________  

Lessons start at: __________  

Playtime is at: __________  

School finishes at: __________  

I arrive home at: __________  

I eat at: __________  

I go to bed at: __________  

[STRDGM] A grid with three columns labeled "Time in Words," "Digital," and "Analogue," where students fill in the times. The digital column has empty boxes for time entries, and the analogue column has empty clock faces for drawing the corresponding times. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Continuation Exercise, Time Sequences) D 4 (With Illustration)

Continue the following time sequences:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 4:00 a.m., 4:20 a.m., 4:40 a.m., \_\_\_\_, \_\_\_\_
\item 7:10 p.m., 9:10 p.m., 11:10 p.m., \_\_\_\_, \_\_\_\_
\item 9:40 a.m., 10:40 a.m., 11:40 a.m., \_\_\_\_, \_\_\_\_
\item 10:35 a.m., 11:05 a.m., 11:35 a.m., \_\_\_\_, \_\_\_\_
\item 5:20 p.m., 5:30 p.m., 5:40 p.m., \_\_\_\_, \_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A list of time sequences where students continue the patterns of times, with some entries already filled in. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (World Time Conversion, Matching Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration)

Given the following cities and their respective time differences from London:

\begin{itemize}
    \item Anchorage in Alaska (5 hours behind London)
    \item Guadalajara in Mexico (6 hours behind London)
    \item São Paulo in Brazil (3 hours behind London)
    \item Paris in France (1 hour ahead of London)
    \item Doha in Qatar (3 hours ahead of London)
    \item Bangalore in India (5.5 hours ahead of London)
    \item Osaka in Japan (9 hours ahead of London)
    \item Wellington in New Zealand (12 hours ahead of London)
\end{itemize}

If it is 3:00 PM in London, what time is it in each of the cities listed above?

[STRDGM] A table listing various cities with their respective time differences from London, prompting students to calculate the local time based on a given London time. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ordering Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration)

Arrange the following events in chronological order based on the times provided:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item 8:00 AM - Wake up
\item 8:30 AM - Have breakfast
\item 9:00 AM - Go to school
\item 12:00 PM - Have lunch
\item 3:00 PM - Finish school
\item 4:00 PM - Play with friends
\item 6:00 PM - Have dinner
\item 7:00 PM - Do homework
\item 8:00 PM - Take a shower
\item 8:30 PM - Read a book
\item 9:00 PM - Prepare for bed
\item 9:30 PM - Sleep
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A series of events depicted with illustrations of children and a clock, where students must arrange the events in chronological order based on the times provided. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance Calculation) D 4 (With Illustration)

Eight cars depart on a 1000 km journey. How far does each car still have to reach 1000 km?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item If Car A has traveled 250 km, how far does it have left to reach 1000 km?
\item If Car B has traveled 400 km, how far does it have left to reach 1000 km?
\item If Car C has traveled 600 km, how far does it have left to reach 1000 km?
\item If Car D has traveled 800 km, how far does it have left to reach 1000 km?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A table listing each car (Car A, Car B, Car C, Car D) and the distance they have traveled, with space to calculate the remaining distance to 1000 km. [STPDGM]

\item \( 37 + 21 = \)
\item \( 24 + 19 = \)
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Grid Completion, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Complete this addition grid:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c}
+ & 15 & 42 & 21 & 37 & 53 & 29 & 64 \\
\hline
19 &   &   &   &   &   &   &   \\
\hline
33 &   &   &   &   &   &   &   \\
\end{array}
\]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Multi-part) D 2 (With Answer)

The chickens laid 18 eggs on Monday and 23 eggs on Tuesday. How many eggs altogether?  

There were 27 students in one class and 28 in another class. How many students altogether? 

\subsection{Answers}
The total number of eggs is 41 and the total number of students is 55.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Number Story Creation) D 2 M

Create a number story that describes a situation where 25 and 19 are added together to equal 44. For example, you could describe a scenario involving people, animals, or objects that leads to this calculation.

(Mathematics) (Number Pairs for Addition) D 2 (With Illustration)

Write the six number pairs that add up to 10. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item (0, 10)
\item (1, 9)
\item (2, 8)
\item (3, 7)
\item (4, 6)
\item (5, 5)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of the number pairs, showing each pair connected by a line to indicate addition. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Addition Exercise) D 2 (With Answer, Multi-part)

Use the number pairs to help you add these numbers. The first one has been done for you.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item 8 + 5 + 2 = 15
\item 1 + 6 + 9 = 
\item 8 + 4 + 6 = 
\item 5 + 5 + 4 = 
\item 4 + 5 + 6 = 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
1. 16  
2. 18  
3. 19  
4. 15  
5. 15

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 = \)
\item \( 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + 6 = \)
\item \( 2 + 2 + 6 + 6 = \)
\item \( 7 + 6 + 5 + 4 + 3 = \)
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Shuffle and Add Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Remove 0 from a set of digit cards numbered 1 to 9. Shuffle the cards and turn over the top five cards. Add the values of these cards together. Rearrange the cards in a different order to help you add them. Shuffle the cards and turn over the top five again.

\begin{equation*}
______ + ______ + ______ + ______ + ______ = ______
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of five turned-over digit cards with their values shown. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (Multi-part)

Complete the five times table up to \( 10 \times 5 \).

\begin{align*}
0 \times 5 & = 0 \\
1 \times 5 & = 5 \\
2 \times 5 & = 10 \\
3 \times 5 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
4 \times 5 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
5 \times 5 & = 25 \\
6 \times 5 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
7 \times 5 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
8 \times 5 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
9 \times 5 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
10 \times 5 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
\end{align*}

[STRDGM] A table format with rows for each multiplication step from 0 to 10 with corresponding results. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (Multi-part)

Complete the ten times table up to \(10 \times 10\).

\begin{align*}
0 \times 10 & = 0 \\
1 \times 10 & = 10 \\
2 \times 10 & = 20 \\
3 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
4 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
5 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
6 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
7 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
8 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
9 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
10 \times 10 & = \underline{\hspace{2cm}} \\
\end{align*}

[STRDGM] A table format with rows for each multiplication step from 0 to 10 with corresponding results. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Proportion Calculation, Word Problem) D 5 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

There are 10 counters. 6 counters are yellow and 4 counters are green. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What proportion of the counters is yellow? Write this using another fraction.
\item What proportion of the counters is green? Write this using another fraction.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing 10 counters, with 6 yellow counters and 4 green counters clearly labeled. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Proportion Calculation) D 5 (With Illustration)

A pizza is divided into 12 pieces. Sami eats three pieces. What proportion of the pizza is left? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What fraction of the pizza is left?
\item What percentage of the pizza is left?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram of a pizza divided into 12 equal slices, with 3 slices removed and the remaining 9 slices highlighted. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Proportion Calculation, Word Problem) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

A bowl contains 12 different kinds of fruit. There are 6 kiwi fruit, 4 mangos, and 2 bananas. What proportion of the fruit are:  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item bananas? Write this using another fraction.
\item kiwi fruit?
\item mangos?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A bowl filled with 12 pieces of fruit, with 6 kiwi, 4 mangoes, and 2 bananas visibly represented. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Proportion Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

A pie is made with bananas and oranges. There is a total of 6 kg of fruit in the pie. The proportion of bananas is \( \frac{2}{3} \). How many kilograms of oranges are there?

\subsection{Answers}
There are 2 kg of oranges. 

[STRDGM] A pie chart showing the distribution of 6 kg of fruit, with 4 kg of bananas and 2 kg of oranges labeled. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Proportion Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

There are 28 students in a class. 16 of the students are girls. What proportion of the students are boys? Write your answer in two ways.

\subsection{Answers}
The proportion of boys is \( \frac{12}{28} \) or \( \frac{3}{7} \).

[STRDGM] A classroom scene with 28 students, 16 girls and 12 boys, clearly labeled. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Problem-solving) D 5 (With Illustration)

Aran has a collection of toy animals. \( \frac{1}{2} \) are lions, \( \frac{3}{10} \) are monkeys, and \( \frac{1}{5} \) are giraffes. Calculate possible numbers of each animal.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many lions are there?
\item How many monkeys are there?
\item How many giraffes are there?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A collection of toy animals with labels indicating the proportions of lions, monkeys, and giraffes. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Problem-solving) D 5 (With Illustration)

India has a bowl of fruit. \( \frac{1}{4} \) are apples, \( \frac{1}{3} \) are papayas, \( \frac{1}{6} \) are mangos, and the other fruit are bananas. Calculate the possible numbers of each fruit.

\subsection{Answers}
Let the total number of fruits be \( x \). Then:
- Number of apples = \( \frac{1}{4}x \)
- Number of papayas = \( \frac{1}{3}x \)
- Number of mangos = \( \frac{1}{6}x \)
- Number of bananas = \( x - \left(\frac{1}{4}x + \frac{1}{3}x + \frac{1}{6}x\right) \)

To find a common denominator, we can use 12:
- Number of apples = \( \frac{3}{12}x \)
- Number of papayas = \( \frac{4}{12}x \)
- Number of mangos = \( \frac{2}{12}x \)

Adding these fractions gives:
\[
\frac{3}{12}x + \frac{4}{12}x + \frac{2}{12}x = \frac{9}{12}x
\]
Thus, the number of bananas is:
\[
x - \frac{9}{12}x = \frac{3}{12}x = \frac{1}{4}x
\]

The total number of fruits must be a multiple of the least common multiple of the denominators (4, 3, and 6), which is 12. Therefore, possible values for \( x \) could be 12, 24, 36, etc.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Problem-solving) D 5 (With Illustration)

Cian has a collection of coins. \( \frac{1}{3} \) are cents, \( \frac{1}{6} \) are 10c coins, and the other coins are 25c coins. Calculate possible numbers of each coin.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many cents does Cian have?
\item How many 10c coins does Cian have?
\item How many 25c coins does Cian have?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A collection of coins with labels indicating that \( \frac{1}{3} \) are cents, \( \frac{1}{6} \) are 10c coins, and the remaining coins are 25c coins. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 5 (With Illustration)

My friend bought a TV in a sale. Before the sale, the price was \$260. In the sale, it was 15\% cheaper. How much cheaper, in \$S, is the TV now?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Discount} = \frac{15}{100} \times 260
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A visual showing the original price of the TV as \$260 and the calculation for the 15\% discount. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Number Manipulation Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Pick four digit cards. Make a 4-digit number. Repeat this so that you have two 4-digit numbers. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Find the total of your two numbers. Use your favourite strategy.
\item Check your total using another strategy.
\item Now find the difference of the two numbers. Use your favourite strategy.
\item Check your difference using another strategy.
\end{enumerate}

Use this grid to record your work:

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Numbers Made & Find the Total & Check & Find the Difference & Check \\
\hline
 &  &  &  &  \\
\hline
 &  &  &  &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

[STRDGM] A grid with five columns labeled "Numbers made," "Find the total," "Check," "Find the difference," and "Check," with empty rows for recording calculations. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Shopping Calculation Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Waleed wants to buy a football game with his pocket money. He has $20. He checks the price of the game at different shops. 

Use the space in the table to show your working:

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Shop} & \textbf{Price} & \textbf{Change from \$20 (show your working)} \\
\hline
\text{Shop 1} & \$10 & \$20 - \$10 = \$10 \\
\hline
\text{Shop 2} & \$15 & \$20 - \$15 = \$5 \\
\hline
\text{Shop 3} & \$25 & \$20 - \$25 = -\$5 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

He wants to buy two games. Has he got enough money? Which shop can he go to?

(Mathematics) (Multiplication Exercise, Table Completion) D 5 (With Illustration)

Practise multiplying numbers by: 

\begin{itemize}
    \item 4 by multiplying by 2 and doubling 
    \item 6 by multiplying by 3 and doubling 
\end{itemize}

Complete the table to show that you can do this. 

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Number} & \textbf{Multiplication by 4} & \textbf{Multiplication by 6} \\
\hline
2 & \( 2 \times 4 = 8 \) & \( 2 \times 6 = 12 \) \\
\hline
3 & \( 3 \times 4 = 12 \) & \( 3 \times 6 = 18 \) \\
\hline
4 & \( 4 \times 4 = 16 \) & \( 4 \times 6 = 24 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

[STRDGM] A table with columns for numbers, multiplication by 4, and multiplication by 6, with example calculations shown for guidance. [STPDGM]

\item Write each pair again, changing the order of the numbers.

Use a set of digit cards. Work with a partner. 

1. You and your partner pick three digit cards and each make a 3-digit number.
2. Add your numbers together. Keep one of the numbers whole and add the hundreds, then tens, and then ones of the other number.
3. Next, take the smallest number away from the largest in the same way.
4. Record your work in the table below. Show how you added and subtracted.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}

\textbf{Numbers Made} & \textbf{Addition} & \textbf{Subtraction} \\
\hline

\hline
 &  &  \\
\hline
 &  &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Multi-part) D 3 (With Illustration)

Solve the following word problems.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item The screwdriver in my toolbox is 18 cm long. 
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item What is the length of the hammer?
   \item How much longer is the screwdriver than one of the screws?
   \end{enumerate}

\item I have three books. They weigh 350 grams, 225 grams, and 375 grams. 
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item What is the total weight of the three books?
   \item Is this more or less than 1 kg? By how much?
   \end{enumerate}

\item I should drink 3 litres of water per day. 
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item How much have I drunk in total?
   \item Is this more or less than 3 litres? By how much?
   \end{enumerate}

\item I bought two different items and received 24 cents change from 1 dollar. 
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item How much did I spend altogether?
   \item How might each item have cost? Write down five different possibilities.
   \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Images of a screwdriver, hammer, screws, three books, a glass of water, and coins including a dollar bill and various cents. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Sieve of Eratosthenes Exercise, Prime and Composite Numbers Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Use this 100 square to make a sieve of Eratosthenes: 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item Shade the number 1.
\item The number 2 is a prime number. Shade the number 2.
\item The number 3 is a prime number. Shade the number 3.
\item Cross out the multiples of 2.
\item Repeat with the next prime number.
\item Now list all the prime numbers up to 100: 
\end{enumerate}

Prime numbers: 2, 3, 5, 7, ...

[STRDGM] A grid of numbers from 1 to 100, with the number 1 shaded, the numbers 2 and 3 shaded, and multiples of 2 crossed out to indicate prime and composite numbers. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Game, Word Problem) D 5 (With Illustration)

Work with a partner. Take turns to roll the dice. Each roll, move that number of squares. Choose any two-digit number (but don’t use a multiple of 10). Multiply the number on the square by the two-digit number you have chosen. Ask your partner to check your answer: For a correct answer, stay on that square. For an incorrect answer, miss your next turn. The first person to arrive at the end wins.

[STRDGM] A game board layout with a starting point labeled "Start" and an endpoint labeled "End," with various multiplication problems on squares in between. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Number Pairs Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (Multi-part)

Use the numbers from 0 to 10 to find all the number pairs for 10. You can only use each number once. Cross out each number as you use it. The first one has been done for you:

\[
0 + 10 = 10
\]

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Write each pair again, changing the order of the numbers in each row. The first one has been done for you:
\[
10 + 0 = 10
\]
\item Did you use all the numbers? Which number is left?
\item Write the number pair for 10 using this number.
\item How many different number pairs for 10 are there?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid with numbers from 0 to 10 at the top, and spaces for writing pairs of numbers that add up to 10 below. The first pair (0 + 10) is already filled in. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Rounding Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 2 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Use the completed 100 square to help you round these numbers to the nearest 10.

\begin{enumerate}
\item 62 
\item 89 
\item 25 
\item 55 
\item 37 
\item 3 
\item 31 
\item 20 
\item 5 
\end{enumerate}

If the ones digit is 4 or less, you round ____________.

If the ones digit is 5 or more, you round ____________.

[STRDGM] A 10x10 grid labeled with numbers from 0 to 100, with the first column filled in with tens numbers. There are blank spaces for rounding numbers and completing sentences about rounding. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Activity, Number Creation Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Pick four cards. Make a 4-digit number. 

Write your number down. 

Rearrange the cards to make another 4-digit number. 

Write an addition or subtraction problem with your two numbers. 

Solve your problem. 

Repeat this several times. 

Write both addition and subtraction problems. 

Record your work in the table below.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Digit Cards} & \textbf{4-Digit Numbers} & \textbf{Problem} & \textbf{Show How You Found the Answer} \\
\hline
 &  &  &  \\
\hline
 &  &  &  \\
\hline
 &  &  &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table} 

[STRDGM] A table with columns labeled "Digit cards," "4-digit numbers," "Problem," and "Show how you found the answer." Each row is empty for students to fill in their work. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Activity, Number Manipulation) D 5 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

- Pick three digit cards to create a 3-digit number.
- Rearrange the digits to form two additional 3-digit numbers.
- Calculate the total of your three numbers.
- Write the strategy you used in the table below.
- Find the differences between pairs of your numbers.
- Write the strategy you used in the table below.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Digits Picked} & \textbf{Numbers Made} & \textbf{Addition} & \textbf{Difference} & \textbf{Strategy} \\ \hline
 &  &  &  &  \\ \hline
 &  &  &  &  \\ \hline
 &  &  &  &  \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Problem Creation) D 5 (With Illustration)

Create an addition and subtraction problem using the numbers 8 and 3. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is \( 8 + 3 \)?
\item What is \( 8 - 3 \)?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual representation showing 8 apples and 3 apples being added together, and then 3 apples being taken away from the 8 apples. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration)

Match these number pairs to make 1.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 0.0
\item 0.1
\item 0.2
\item 0.3
\item 0.4
\item 0.5
\item 0.6
\item 0.7
\item 0.8
\item 0.9
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid with numbers from 0.0 to 0.9 on the left and 0.3 to 0.7 on the right, with lines connecting matching pairs that sum to 1. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Sonny cycled 24.8 km. He then stopped for a rest. The ride was 25 km long in total. How much longer did he have to cycle?

\subsection{Answers}
He had to cycle 0.2 km longer. 

[STRDGM] A simple illustration of a cyclist on a road, with a distance marker showing 24.8 km and a sign indicating a total of 25 km. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Mara has 2.4 kg of apples. She needs 3 kg of apples. How much more does she need?

\subsection{Answers}
Mara needs 0.6 kg more apples.


(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration)

Match the number pairs to make 10.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 0.0 \quad \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 5 (With Illustration)

Nabila was on a 10 km run. She stopped for a rest after 2.7 km. How much further did she have to run?

[STRDGM] An illustration of a runner on a path, with a distance marker showing 2.7 km and a total distance of 10 km indicated. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Tareq has \$8.60. He needs \$10 to buy a pair of shorts. How much more does he need?

\subsection{Answers}
He needs \$1.40 more.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Samir is filling a 10 L bucket with water. He fills it to 5.3 L. How much more water does he need to fill the bucket?

\subsection{Answers}
He needs 4.7 L more water. 

[STRDGM] An illustration of a man pouring water into a bucket, with a gauge showing 5.3 L filled in a 10 L bucket and an indication of the remaining 4.7 L needed to fill it to 10 L. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Subtraction Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Write the two related subtraction facts for the number pair: \( 80 + 20 = 100 \) and \( 20 + 80 = 100 \).

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the first related subtraction fact?
\item What is the second related subtraction fact?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid with boxes for writing answers, showing pairs of numbers related to addition and subtraction: \( 100 - 80 = \_\_\_ \) and \( 100 - 20 = \_\_\_ \). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Fact Family Identification, Matching Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Circle the number which does not belong to the fact family.

[STRDGM] A series of number groups, for example: \(3, 4, 7\) where \(7\) is highlighted and surrounded by a box, indicating it does not fit the fact family of \(3 + 4 = 7\) and \(7 - 4 = 3\). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Sentence Completion) D 2 (With Illustration)

Complete the following sentence using the word bigger or smaller: 

10 is _______ than 100.

[STRDGM] A blank line for writing the completed sentence about the number pairs 10 and 100. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Fact Family Writing, Arithmetic Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Write the fact family for each number pair for 100 using multiples of 10.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 10 and 90
\item 20 and 80
\item 30 and 70
\item 40 and 60
\item 50 and 50
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Counting Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Multi-part)

Complete these steps:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 2574 + 1000 \rightarrow \_\_ \rightarrow -10 \rightarrow -100 \rightarrow +1 \)  
\item \( 4892 + 10 \rightarrow \_\_ \rightarrow -100 \rightarrow +1 \)  
\item \( 7198 + 1000 \rightarrow \_\_ \rightarrow -10 \rightarrow -100 \rightarrow +1 \)  
\item \( 6920 + 1000 \rightarrow \_\_ \rightarrow -10 \rightarrow -100 \rightarrow +1 \)  
\item \( 1099 + 1000 \rightarrow \_\_ \rightarrow -10 \rightarrow -100 \rightarrow +1 \)  
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Table Completion) D 4 (With Illustration)

Look at the numbers in the middle column of this table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
-1000 & -100 & -10 & \text{Number} & +10 & +100 & +1000 \\
\hline
123 & 1123 & 1223 & 1234 & 1245 & 1345 & 2345 \\
\hline
3261 & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ \\
\hline
4075 & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ \\
\hline
2184 & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ \\
\hline
7413 & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ \\
\hline
6099 & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ \\
\hline
7909 & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ & \_\_ \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

Fill in the blanks in the middle column based on the pattern of the numbers.


(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise, Number Pairs) D 4 (Multi-part)

Use these number cards: 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 0. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Make as many pairs of 4-digit numbers as you can that have a difference of 100.  
\item Now make pairs of 4-digit numbers with a difference of 1000.  
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Partner Activity, Word Problem) D 4 (Multi-part)

A number adventure!  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Work with a partner.  
\item Choose a 3-digit number.  
\item Take your number on this adventure:  
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
  \item Add 2000  
  \item Take away 2  
  \item Add 200  
  \item Take away 10  
  \end{enumerate}
\item Check with your partner.  
\item Write your own number adventure using a 4-digit number.  
\item Give your number adventure to your partner to test it.  
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Score Difference Calculation, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Here are some computer games scores.  

Work out the difference between the start score and the new score:  

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Start Score} & \textbf{New Score} & \textbf{Difference} \\
\hline
4560 & 4660 & ___ \\
2913 & 3113 & ___ \\
7521 & 9521 & ___ \\
1309 & 1349 & ___ \\
3189 & 4289 & ___ \\
8732 & 8738 & ___ \\
5689 & 6089 & ___ \\
\hline
\end{tabular} 

Calculate the difference for each pair of scores.


(Mathematics) (Tile Design, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Draw three different designs for the classroom floor and work out the cost for each design based on the following information:

- Each tile costs \$2.
- Design 1 uses 10 tiles.
- Design 2 uses 15 tiles.
- Design 3 uses 12 tiles.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Create a tile pattern for Design 1 in the provided grid.
\item Create a tile pattern for Design 2 in the provided grid.
\item Create a tile pattern for Design 3 in the provided grid.
\item Calculate the total cost for each design.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Three empty grids labeled Design 1, Design 2, and Design 3 are provided for creating tile patterns. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Comparison Exercise, Box Comparison Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Pick up the largest box.  

Pick up the smallest box.  

Which is the heaviest?  

Box number _______ is the heaviest.  

Box number _______ is the lightest.  

Box number _______ is lighter than box number __________.  

Write the numbers of the boxes in order, from lightest to heaviest.  

[STRDGM] A diagram showing three boxes of different sizes and weights, labeled as box number 1, box number 2, and box number 3. The largest box is at the top, the smallest at the bottom, and arrows indicating weight comparisons. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Measuring Length and Weight, Fill in the Blank) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

How long is the table?  

\begin{itemize}
\item hands: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\item feet: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\item cubes: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\item straws: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\end{itemize}

How long is your leg?  

\begin{itemize}
\item hands: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\item feet: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\item cubes: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\item straws: \underline{\hspace{2cm}}  
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating a table with measurements taken using hands, feet, cubes, and straws, along with a leg being measured similarly. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Weight Comparison Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Use cubes for weighing.  

My shoe weighs _______ cubes.  

My book weighs _______ cubes.  

5 pencils weigh _______ cubes.  

2 scissors and 5 pencils weigh _______ cubes.  

A jug weighs _______ cubes.  

2 shoes weigh _______ cubes.  

3 books weigh _______ cubes.  

20 cubes weigh _______ cubes.  

Which was longer, the table or your leg?  

The _______ was longer.  

Which was shorter, the table or your leg?  

The _______ was shorter.  

What weighed the most?  

_________ weighed the most.  

What weighed less than your shoe?  

_________ weighed less than my shoe.  

What weighed more than 5 pencils?  

_________ weighed more than 5 pencils.  

[STRDGM] A diagram showing various items (shoe, book, pencils, scissors, jug) with cubes for weight comparison, and a table and leg for length comparison. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Estimating Capacity Exercise, Word Problem) D 1 (With Illustration)

Look at the containers on the table.  

Which of these do you think would hold the most?  

Draw them in the order that you think.  

How could we find out?  

Fill them with cubes.  

Tip them out one at a time.  

Count the cubes that were inside.  

[STRDGM] A diagram showing several containers of different sizes and shapes, with cubes beside them for filling and measuring capacity. [STPDGM]

\item Write the timetable below.
\item Why is this the best day for the trip?
\end{enumerate}

The first number line should have a marked point at \(4\) and an arrow indicating the jump to \(14\). The second number line should have pairs of numbers to be joined, such as \(1\) with \(11\), \(2\) with \(12\), and so on, up to \(10\) with \(20\). [STPDGM]

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 90°
\item 45°
\item 30°
\item 60°
\end{enumerate}
What others can you make? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Cut your angles out.
\item Draw each angle here.
\item Under each angle, write how you made it.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Counting Exercise, Coloring Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Which numbers could you make with your place value counters? You do not have to use all the counters when you make a number. Colour the numbers you can make on the 100 square.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Which numbers was it not possible to make? 
\item Tell a friend why you cannot make these numbers. I can’t make ____________ because ____________.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A 10x10 grid filled with numbers from 1 to 100, arranged in rows. Each cell contains a single number, with the first row starting from 1 to 10 and continuing sequentially down to 100 in the last row. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Drawing Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Draw the matching counters for each number:

26: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\


(Mathematics) (Estimating Exercise, Hands-on Activity) D 4 (With Illustration)

Choose six similar toys. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Hold the toys in your hands to feel how heavy they are.
\item Try to estimate the order from lightest to heaviest.
\item Record your order in the table below.
\item Estimate the mass in grams.
\item Now use the balance to find the exact mass of each item.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Order} & \textbf{Estimated Mass (grams)} & \textbf{Accurate Mass (grams)} \\
\hline
1 & & \\
\hline
2 & & \\
\hline
3 & & \\
\hline
4 & & \\
\hline
5 & & \\
\hline
6 & & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\caption{Table for recording estimates and accurate masses of toys.}
\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Problem Solving, Word Problem) D 4 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

Which is heavier: a small container full of oil or an identical container full of water?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Write a prediction: "We think that ... because ...".
\item Discuss with your partner how you can test your prediction. Then try it out.
\item What did you find out?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A question prompt with space for prediction and discussion notes. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Calculating Mass, Word Problem) D 4 (Multi-part)

Try these problems. Show how you worked them out.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item A coin has a mass of 20g. What is the mass of 8 coins?
\item A crate of apples has a mass of 5kg. The empty crate is 400g. What is the actual mass of the apples?
\item A cake has a mass of 400g. You cut it into six pieces. What is the mass of each piece?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A section with three problems, each requiring calculations based on given weights. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Analyzing Data, Table Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

This table shows the masses of different fruits:

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Fruit} & \textbf{Mass (g)} \\
\hline
Lemon & 110 \\
Orange & 300 \\
Apple & 160 \\
Pineapple & 880 \\
Banana & 170 \\
Melon & 1000 \\
Lime & 900 \\
Mango & 260 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Which fruits have a mass of less than 1kg?
\item Which fruits have a mass greater than 1/2 kg?
\item Which fruits have a mass between 1/2 kg and 1 kg?
\item Which two fruits have a total mass of 1kg?
\item Which two fruits have the same mass as the mango?
\item Which three fruits have a total mass of 1kg?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A table with images of fruits and their corresponding masses. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Completing Mass Scales, Measurement Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration)

Complete the scales in both grams and kilograms.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Fill in the missing gram markings on the scale from 0 kg to 1 kg.
\item Fill in the corresponding kilogram markings on the scale.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A scale diagram showing increments from 0 kg to 1 kg, with corresponding gram markings at 0 g, 250 g, 500 g, 750 g, and 1000 g. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Estimating Exercise, Multi-part) D 4 (With Illustration)

You need: a set of metric masses, an electronic balance.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Collect six items from the classroom that you think have a mass less than a kilogram.
\item Hold a known mass in one hand and an object in your other hand.
\item Estimate the mass of the object in grams.
\item Record your estimate.
\item Place the object on the electronic balance.
\item Record the exact mass in the table.
\item Repeat with the other items.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A table for recording estimates and actual masses of six classroom items, with columns for "Item Description," "Estimated Mass (g)," and "Actual Mass (g)." [STPDGM]

    \item Bananas: 15
    \item Cherries: 5

Our question is __________________________________.

(Mathematics) (Writing Time in Words, Fill in the Blank) D 4 (Multi-part)

Here are some times. Write each time in words. The first is done as an example. 

7.45 a.m. Seven forty-five in the morning. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 9.15 a.m. __________. 
\item 12.30 p.m. __________. 
\item 3.45 p.m. __________. 
\item 7.40 p.m. __________. 
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Place Value Game, Activity) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Use a set of 0-9 digit cards to find the largest and smallest numbers, and the nearest numbers to 5 million and 8 million.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the largest number you can create using the digit cards?
\item What is the smallest number you can create using the digit cards?
\item What is the nearest number to 5 million that you can create?
\item What is the nearest number to 8 million that you can create?
\end{enumerate}

Repeat the place value game for hundreds, tens, and decimal points.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the largest number you can create using the digit cards for hundreds, tens, and decimal points?
\item What is the smallest number you can create using the digit cards for hundreds, tens, and decimal points?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid with columns labeled Millions, Hundred thousands, Ten thousands, Thousands, Hundreds, Tens, and Units, with spaces for the largest number, smallest number, and nearest values. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Use a calculator to multiply a four-digit number by 10, 100, and 1000, and write the answers in the place value grid.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Choose a four-digit number (e.g., 2345).
\item Calculate the results of multiplying the number by 10, 100, and 1000.
\item Record the results in the place value grid below.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid with columns labeled Millions, Hundred thousands, Ten thousands, Thousands, Hundreds, Tens, and Units for recording results. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Sorting Exercise, Classification Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Sort the shapes and complete the Carroll diagram based on the number of sides.

[STRDGM] The image includes various geometric shapes: a pentagon (5 sides), a semi-circle (0 sides), a trapezium (4 sides), a triangle (3 sides), a circle (0 sides), a square (4 sides), a rectangle (4 sides), a hexagon (6 sides), an oval (0 sides), and a kite (4 sides), which need to be categorized based on the number of sides. [STPDGM]

Identify which shapes have curved sides.

[STRDGM] The shapes that need to be analyzed for curved sides include a semi-circle, a circle, and an oval. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Direction Following Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Follow the directions. Which shape does the robot walk to?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Forwards 3 squares, left turn, forwards 3 squares, right turn, backwards 2 squares. 
\item Forwards 3 squares, left turn, forwards 3 squares, right turn, forwards 4 squares, left turn, forwards 4 squares. 
\item Forwards 3 squares, left turn, forwards 3 squares, right turn, forwards 1 square, left turn, forwards 4 squares. 
\item Forwards 3 squares, left turn, forwards 3 squares, right turn, forwards 3 squares, right turn, forwards 3 squares, left turn, forwards 2 squares. 
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid with squares marked, showing the robot's path based on the directions given. Each square represents a unit of movement. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise, Shape Identification Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

The shape moves a quarter-turn anti-clockwise. Tick the correct shape in each row.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 
\begin{itemize}
    \item [1.] Original shape
    \item [2.] Shape after a quarter-turn anti-clockwise
    \item [3.] Incorrect shape
\end{itemize}

\item 
\begin{itemize}
    \item [1.] Original shape
    \item [2.] Shape after a quarter-turn anti-clockwise
    \item [3.] Incorrect shape
\end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Two rows of shapes, with arrows indicating the direction of movement for each shape. The first row shows different orientations of a triangle, while the second row presents variations of a square. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Venn Diagram Sorting, Sorting Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Sort the numbers. Write them in the Venn diagram: 50, 45, 52, 54, 40, 30, 35, 25, 20, 22, 18. Now add six more of your own numbers.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

Manuel visited his grandmother on Monday. He stayed for three days. On which day of the week did Manuel return home?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What day did Manuel visit his grandmother?
\item What day did he return home?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

It is a Saturday today. Lucia’s birthday is in four days’ time. On which day of the week is Lucia’s birthday this year?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What day of the week will it be in four days?
\item What day of the week is Lucia’s birthday?
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

Carlos posted a parcel on Wednesday to a friend. The parcel took two days to arrive at his friend’s house. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item On which day of the week did the parcel arrive?
\item If the parcel had taken one more day to arrive, what day would it have arrived?
\end{enumerate}

\item 11 o’clock
\item 4 o’clock
\end{itemize}

b) How many months are there in two years?

\item 1 o’clock
\item half past 2
\item 7 o’clock
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Direction Writing Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Pointed Hill: Forward 1, \( \frac{1}{4} \) turn clockwise, forward 2, \( \frac{1}{4} \) turn clockwise, forward 2.

The Hut: 

Orange trees then Coconut trees: 

Coconut trees then Skull Hill: 

Skull Hill then the Hut:

(Mathematics) (Ordering Exercise) D 2 (With Illustration)

Put the days of the week in order, starting with Monday.

(Mathematics) (Day Comparison Questions) D 2 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Two different days begin with S. Which day comes first in the week? 
Two different days begin with T. Which day comes later in the week? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Write the names of the days that begin with S.
\item Write the names of the days that begin with T.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Blank lines for writing answers to the questions about the days starting with S and T. [STPDGM]

Which day comes before Wednesday? 
What is the 3rd day of the week? 
What is the 5th day of the week?

(Mathematics) (Number Facts Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Make any two-digit number. Write it below. Write down 5 facts about this number.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\


(Mathematics) (Number Facts Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Pick another two-digit number. Write it below. Write down 5 facts about this number.

\begin{itemize}
\item Two-digit number: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\


(Mathematics) (Number Facts Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Pick any three-digit number. Write it below. Write down 5 facts about this number.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ (Three-digit number)
\item Fact 1: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Fact 2: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Fact 3: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Fact 4: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Fact 5: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A blank space for writing a three-digit number and five facts about it. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Number Facts Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Pick a different three-digit number. Write it below and list 5 facts about this number.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\

3. Additionally, a third number line shows my jumps from 3 to 12 in increments of 5, and back from 16 to 4 in increments of 2, marked with numbers from 0 to 16. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Comparison Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

April had \$23.95. Faith had \$23.50. 

Who had the most money? 

Write the amounts in two number sentences using the \( < \) and \( > \) symbols:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item April's amount compared to Faith's amount: \( 23.95 \, > \, 23.50 \)
\item Faith's amount compared to April's amount: \( 23.50 \, < \, 23.95 \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
April had the most money.


(Mathematics) (Comparison Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

Greg had 124 shells. Hope had 142 shells. 

Who had the most shells? 

Write the amounts in two number sentences using the \( < \) and \( > \) symbols:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Greg's shells compared to Hope's shells: \( 124 \, ? \, 142 \)
\item Hope's shells compared to Greg's shells: \( 142 \, ? \, 124 \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
Greg's shells compared to Hope's shells: \( 124 < 142 \)  
Hope's shells compared to Greg's shells: \( 142 > 124 \)

\item \( 53 - 9 = \_\_\_\_\_\) \quad \( = \_\_\_\_\_\) \quad \( = \_\_\_\_\_\) \quad \( = \_\_\_\_\_\)  
\item \( 3 + 68 = \_\_\_\_\_\) \quad \( = \_\_\_\_\_\) \quad \( = \_\_\_\_\_\) \quad \( = \_\_\_\_\_\)

How many different ways can you share these cakes fairly?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item If 2 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 3 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 4 people can have exactly \( q \) cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 5 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 6 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 7 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 8 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 9 people can have 3 cakes each with 6 left over, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 10 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 11 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 12 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\item If 13 people can have cakes each, how many cakes are there in total?
\end{enumerate}

\hline

Class D & 15 \\
\hline
\textbf{Total} &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\item \_\_\_\_ + \_\_\_\_ = \_\_\_\_
\item \_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_ = \_\_\_\_
\item \_\_\_\_ + \_\_\_\_ = \_\_\_\_
\item \_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_ = \_\_\_\_
\item \_\_\_\_ + \_\_\_\_ = \_\_\_\_
\item \_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_ = \_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A list format with empty lines for calculations. [STPDGM]

\end{equation*}

(Mathematics) (Data Handling Exercise, Graphing Exercise) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Together, work out the total medals won by each country. On a large piece of paper, create a bar graph using the information from the table below. Decide which information to use, such as the total medals each country has won or the total gold, silver, or bronze medals won. Remember to consider the scale on the vertical axis. What is the best interval to use? Give your graph a title and label each axis. Now make up some statements based on your bar graph.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Country} & \textbf{Gold} & \textbf{Silver} & \textbf{Bronze} & \textbf{Total} \\
\hline
USA & 46 & 29 & 29 & 104 \\
China & 38 & 27 & 23 & 88 \\
Great Britain & 29 & 17 & 19 & 65 \\
Russia & 24 & 26 & 32 & 82 \\
South Korea & 13 & 8 & 7 & 28 \\
Germany & 11 & 19 & 14 & 44 \\
France & 11 & 11 & 12 & 34 \\
Italy & 8 & 9 & 11 & 28 \\
Hungary & 8 & 4 & 6 & 18 \\
Australia & 8 & 11 & 10 & 29 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\caption{Medal counts for the top ten countries in the 2012 Summer Olympics}
\end{table}

[STRDGM] A table showing the medal counts for the top ten countries in the 2012 Summer Olympics, including columns for Gold, Silver, Bronze, and Total medals. The countries listed are USA, China, Great Britain, Russia, South Korea, Germany, France, Italy, Hungary, and Australia, with their respective medal counts. [STPDGM]

The coordinates of cross b are (9, 9). Write the coordinates of the other crosses: a, c, d, e, f, g, h, i, j. The coordinates for these crosses are as follows: 
\begin{itemize}
    \item a: (10, 10)
    \item c: (6, 7)
    \item d: (2, 7)
    \item e: (4, 6)
    \item f: (7, 3)
    \item g: (9, 5)
    \item h: (8, 8) \text{ (example additional coordinate)}
    \item i: (3, 5) \text{ (example additional coordinate)}
    \item j: (1, 2) \text{ (example additional coordinate)}
\end{itemize}

Now plot these coordinates on the grid, marking each with a cross. Join the crosses. What is the shape formed by the crosses?

[STRDGM] A grid with x and y axes labeled from 0 to 10, with crosses plotted at the specified coordinates. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Measurement Exercise, Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

Metre Mouse has a tail 1 metre long. \(1 \text{ m} = 100 \text{ cm}\)  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How long is a Half Metre Mouse tail?  
\item How long is a Quarter Metre Mouse tail?  
\item How long is a Three-Quarter Metre Mouse tail?  
\item How long is a Two-Quarter Metre Mouse tail?  
\item Two mice put their tails end to end. If they are a Half Metre Mouse and a Two-Quarter Metre Mouse, how long are the tails altogether?  
\item A large egg weighs 100g. I follow Grandma’s Simple Sweet Cake recipe using 2 eggs. How much does the cake mixture weigh altogether?  
\item Today I drank three mugs of tea, a 500ml bottle of water, and two glasses of lemonade. My mug holds 300ml and my glass holds 200ml. How much liquid did I drink today?  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The page contains a grid layout with questions related to measurements, including lengths of tails and liquid volumes. Each question has a blank space for answers. [STPDGM]

\item \( 720 \, \text{kg} - 352 \, \text{kg} = \)  
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Card Selection and Number Creation, Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

Pick two cards from a set of 0–9 digit cards. Make two different 2-digit numbers using the selected cards.

[STRDGM] A set of cards numbered 0 to 9, with two cards selected to form the numbers \( AB \) and \( CD \), where \( A \) and \( C \) are the digits from the selected cards. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Colouring Exercise, Activity) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Make two different numbers from your digits. Colour them in on the 100-square. Repeat this process four times.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Choose two different digits and create a number. Colour that number in on the 100-square.
\item Choose another two different digits and create a second number. Colour that number in on the 100-square.
\item Repeat the process with two new pairs of digits.
\item Ensure all four numbers are coloured in on the grid.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A 10x10 grid representing numbers 1 to 100, where specific numbers need to be coloured. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Sentence Completion) D 1 (With Illustration)

Complete these sentences using digits and words: My biggest number is __________ which you write in words as __________. 

[STRDGM] Blank spaces for students to fill in their biggest number and its written form. [STPDGM]

Draw the gloves you found and indicate the total number. 

[STRDGM] A visual representation of gloves, with a count indicated. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Polygon Properties, Table Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration)

Draw the correct shapes in the second column of this table. Write at least three properties for each shape.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Shape Name} & \textbf{Drawing} & \textbf{Properties} \\ \hline
Rectangle & [Drawing of a rectangle] & 1. Opposite sides are equal in length. \\ 
          &                          & 2. All angles are right angles. \\ 
          &                          & 3. The diagonals bisect each other. \\ \hline
Hexagon   & [Drawing of a hexagon] & 1. Has six sides and six angles. \\ 
          &                          & 2. The sum of interior angles is 720 degrees. \\ 
          &                          & 3. Can be regular (all sides and angles equal) or irregular. \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

[STRDGM] A table with columns for shape names, drawings, and properties, including various polygons like rectangles and hexagons. [STPDGM]

\item Two more friends arrive. How much pizza do you get each now?
\end{enumerate}
