(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

Three people are eating chapatis. They eat \( \frac{2}{3} \) of a chapati each. How many chapatis do they eat in total? 

Five people are eating pizza. They eat \( \frac{2}{4} \) of a pizza each. How many pizzas do they eat in total? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many chapatis do they eat in total?
\item How many pizzas do they eat in total?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Illustrations of chapatis and pizzas are shown, with fractions indicating portions eaten. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

Two people are eating small cakes. They eat \( \frac{1}{2} \) each. How many cakes do they eat in total? 

Seven people are eating cookies. They eat \( \frac{1}{3} \) of a cookie each. How many cookies do they eat in total? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many small cakes do the two people eat in total?
\item How many cookies do the seven people eat in total?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Images of small cakes and cookies are presented, with fractions indicating the amount consumed. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Group Activity, Data Collection) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Work in a small group.

Think of something you would like to find out about the class – for example: their favourite animal, sport, or food. You could choose one of these ideas but, better still, think of one of your own.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How will you collect your data?
\item Collect your data.
\item Represent it in a bar line graph with a vertical axis that goes up in intervals of 2.
\item Draw your graph here:
\end{enumerate}

Write some questions on another piece of paper to ask the class about your graph.

[STRDGM] A blank graph space for drawing a bar line graph. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Line Graph Analysis, Word Problem) D 5 (Multi-part)

Look carefully at this line graph.

It shows 12 hours in the life of truck driver Pete.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item How far from home is Pete at 09:00?
\item What do you think he is doing from 09:00 to 10:00?
\item How many kilometres does Pete travel from 10:00 to 11:00?
\item For how many hours does he not travel anywhere?
\item How far from home is he at 13:00?
\item How far from home is he at 16:00?
\item Estimate how far from home he is at 17:30.
\item How many kilometres did Pete travel in total?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A line graph depicting the distance (in kilometres) from home on the vertical axis and time (from 08:00 to 19:00) on the horizontal axis, with data points connected by lines. The graph shows fluctuations in distance throughout the day. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Counting Exercise, Multi-part) D 3 (With Illustration)

1. Complete this number track by counting on or counting back in 2s, 3s, 4s, or 5s. Try to make the final answer the same as the starting number. 

2. Complete this number track by counting on or counting back in 1s, 10s, or 100s. Try to make the final answer the same as the starting number. 

3. Make up a number track of your own.

4. Use a set of 0–9 digit cards. Pick 3 different cards and make a three-digit number. Write the number here: 

[STRDGM] The image shows a number track with various segments marked for counting in different increments (2s, 3s, etc.) and spaces for writing numbers. The second part includes a prompt for creating a three-digit number using digit cards. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Sentence Completion, Fill in the Blank) D 3 (With Illustration)

Complete the sentences below.

My number has __________ in the units column.

My number has __________ in the tens column. This is worth __________.

My number has __________ in the hundreds column. This is worth __________.

My number is 1 more than __________.

My number is 1 less than __________.

My number is 10 more than __________.

My number is 10 less than __________.

My number is 100 more than __________.

My number is 100 less than __________.

[STRDGM] The image contains fill-in-the-blank sentences related to number properties and place value, with spaces for students to write their answers. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Translation Exercise, Instruction Following) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

- Draw a symbol (such as a star or a circle) in the top left corner of this grid.

- Translate your shape following the instructions below. After each move, draw your symbol in its new position.

\begin{enumerate}
  \item Move 3 squares to the right.
  \item Move 4 squares down.
  \item Move 1 square to the left.
  \item Move 3 squares down.
  \item Move 7 squares to the right.
  \item Move 6 squares up.
  \item Move 2 squares to the left.
  \item Move 1 square up.
  \item Move 2 squares to the right.
\end{enumerate}

- Now write your own set of instructions and follow them on this grid.

- Give your instructions to your partner to follow on a piece of squared paper. Is their result the same as yours?

[STRDGM] A grid with empty squares for drawing shapes and writing instructions. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Translation Exercise, Shape Description) D 5 (With Illustration)

This grid shows five shapes translated from one area to another. 

- Describe the translations to your partner.
- Don't go into or across the shaded squares!
- Draw the translations on the grid.
- Now write your instructions here. Use simple instructions. For example: use L for left, R for right, D for down.

[STRDGM] A grid with various shapes (triangle, square, pentagon, circle, and rectangle) placed in different areas, with shaded squares indicating restricted areas. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

What is the sum of 4563 and 2766?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is 7329.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

What is \( 739 \times 6 \)?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is 4434.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

What is \( 267 \div 7 \)?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is \( 38.14 \) (rounded to two decimal places).


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

What is the sum of 5639 and 3976?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is 9615.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

What is \( 376 \div 4 \)?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is \( 94 \).

This is a ______________.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Estimation Exercise) D 2 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

How many millilitres are in half a litre? 
How many millilitres are in a quarter of a litre? 
How many millilitres are in each glass if a litre of lemonade is poured into 5 glasses? 
How many millilitres are in each glass if a litre of lemonade is poured into 4 glasses?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the millilitres in half a litre.
\item Calculate the millilitres in a quarter of a litre.
\item Calculate the millilitres in each glass if a litre of lemonade is poured into 5 glasses.
\item Calculate the millilitres in each glass if a litre of lemonade is poured into 4 glasses.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a measuring jug marked in millilitres and two sets of glasses, one set with 5 glasses and another set with 4 glasses, each filled with lemonade. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Calculation Questions, Word Problem) D 2 (Multi-part)

I have 20 lemons. How many litres of lemonade can I make? How many 500 ml bottles can I fill? How many 200 ml drinks will I have?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the total litres of lemonade that can be made from 20 lemons.
\item Determine how many 500 ml bottles can be filled with the lemonade.
\item Find out how many 200 ml drinks can be made from the lemonade.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of lemons, bottles, and drinks, indicating the quantities for each calculation. [STPDGM]

\begin{itemize}
    \item The number and shapes of the faces.
    \item The number of edges.
    \item The number of vertices.
    \item Whether the shape is a prism or not.
\end{itemize}
Next, draw lines to match each shape with its name.

(Mathematics) (Fractions Exercise, Observational Exercise) D 3 (Multi-part)

Write down all the fractions you can see which are equivalent to \( \frac{1}{2} \): 

\begin{equation*}
\frac{1}{2} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{3}{6} = \frac{5}{10}.
\end{equation*}

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Write down anything you notice about these fractions.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Table Completion, Fill in the Blank) D 6 (With Illustration)

Complete the following fractions and percentages table.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Fraction} & \textbf{Decimal Fraction} & \textbf{Percentage} & \textbf{Percentage as an Area} \\
\hline
\frac{1}{2} &  &  &  \\
\hline
\frac{3}{4} &  &  &  \\
\hline
\frac{1}{5} &  &  &  \\
\hline

(Mathematics) (Multiplication and Division Exercise, Word Problem) D 3 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

There are 4 lettuces in each column, and there are 6 columns. How many lettuces are there in total? 

There are 4 rows of solar panels and 5 columns. How many solar panels are there in total? 

If I divide the total number of solar panels by the number of rows, how many panels will be in each row?

This shows that \( 2 \times 6 = 12 \).

[STRDGM] The image shows a garden with 6 columns of green lettuce plants, each containing 4 lettuces. Additionally, there are 4 rows of solar panels arranged in 5 columns, with a total of 20 solar panels. [STPDGM]

\item For the second number, write the first five terms of the sequence and explain the rule.
\end{enumerate}

Write a calculation using each of the other four numbers. Use what you have learned in this Unit. For example: adding or subtracting units, tens, hundreds or thousands, or partitioning one of your numbers.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (Multi-part)

It takes \(\frac{1}{4}\) of an hour to cook a large tray of biscuits. Only one tray can fit in the oven at a time. How many hours does it take to cook these?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 6 trays of biscuits take _____ hours to cook.  
\item 11 trays of biscuits take _____ hours to cook.  
\item 21 trays of biscuits take _____ hours to cook.  
\item 17 trays of biscuits take _____ hours to cook.  
\item 35 trays of biscuits take _____ hours to cook.  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A kitchen scene with trays of biscuits in an oven, illustrating the cooking process. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Table Filling Exercise) D 4 (With Answer)

Fill in this table. The first three rows are done for you.  

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Half the number} & \text{Number} & \text{Double the number} \\ 
\hline
12 & 24 & 48 \\ 
\hline
120 & 240 & 480 \\ 
\hline
1200 & 2400 & 4800 \\ 
\hline
46 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
460 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
4600 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
28 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
280 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
2800 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
34 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
340 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
3400 & \_\_\_\_\_ & \_\_\_\_\_ \\ 
\hline
\end{array}
\]

\subsection{Answers}
\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Half the number} & \text{Number} & \text{Double the number} \\ 
\hline
12 & 24 & 48 \\ 
\hline
120 & 240 & 480 \\ 
\hline
1200 & 2400 & 4800 \\ 
\hline
46 & 92 & 92 \\ 
\hline
460 & 920 & 920 \\ 
\hline
4600 & 9200 & 9200 \\ 
\hline
28 & 56 & 56 \\ 
\hline
280 & 560 & 560 \\ 
\hline
2800 & 5600 & 5600 \\ 
\hline
34 & 68 & 68 \\ 
\hline
340 & 680 & 680 \\ 
\hline
3400 & 6800 & 6800 \\ 
\hline
\end{array}
\]

\item Subtracting a negative number from a positive number always results in a larger positive number.
\item Adding two negative numbers results in a positive number.
\item Subtracting a positive number from a negative number always results in a negative number.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Length Pairing Exercise, Matching Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Draw a straight line to join each pair of lengths that add up to 1 km (1000 m). If you do it correctly, you will get three squares.

[STRDGM] The exercise features various lengths in meters: 250 m, 750 m, 400 m, 600 m, and 500 m, with some lengths placed in a scattered manner. There are three pairs of lengths that, when added together, equal 1 km (1000 m): (250 m + 750 m), (400 m + 600 m), and (500 m + 500 m). The task is to connect these pairs with straight lines. The background includes a cartoon character thinking about the conversion of kilometers to meters. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Multi-part) D 3 (With Answer)

Perform the following compound unit subtractions:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 3 \text{ km } 900 \text{ m} - 1 \text{ km } 250 \text{ m} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ km } \_\_\_\_ \text{ m} \)  
\item \( 8 \text{ km } 440 \text{ m} - 2 \text{ km } 520 \text{ m} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ km } \_\_\_\_ \text{ m} \)  
\item \( 5 \text{ km } 30 \text{ m} - 1 \text{ km } 280 \text{ m} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ km } \_\_\_\_ \text{ m} \)  
\item \( 9 \text{ km } 720 \text{ m} - 2 \text{ km } 800 \text{ m} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ km } \_\_\_\_ \text{ m} \)  
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 2 \text{ km } 650 \text{ m} \)  
\item \( 5 \text{ km } 920 \text{ m} \)  
\item \( 3 \text{ km } 750 \text{ m} \)  
\item \( 6 \text{ km } 920 \text{ m} \)  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A cartoon character with a puzzled look, scratching their head as they contemplate the subtraction of compound units. [STPDGM]

(a) The weight of the bag of rice is given as \( x \) kg. 

(b) The cost of the bag of rice is $5. What is the cost of 1 kg of rice?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Cost per kg} = \frac{\text{Total Cost}}{\text{Weight of the bag}} = \frac{5}{x}
\end{equation*}

\subsection{Answers}

\subsection{Answers}

[STRDGM] A scale showing two bunches of lychees, one labeled \( 2 \, \text{kg} \, 750 \, \text{g} \) and the other labeled \( 2 \, \text{kg} \, 860 \, \text{g} \), with a total weight calculation area. [STPDGM]

\end{equation*}

(Mathematics) (Multiplication Exercises) D 6 (Multi-part, With Answer)

a) \( 346 \times 7 = ( ___ \times 7) + (40 \times ___) + ( ___ \times 7) = __________ \)  

b) \( 54.92 \times 3 = (4 \times 3) + (0.9 \times ___) + ( ___ \times 3) = __________ \)  

c) \( 685 \times 6 = ( ___ \times 6) + (80 \times ___) + ( ___ \times 6) = __________ \)  

d) \( 4.56 \times 4 = ( ___ \times 4) + (0.5 \times ___) + ( ___ \times 4) = __________ \)  

e) \( 532 \times 8 = __________ \)  

f) \( 8.26 \times 5 = __________ \)  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item A multiplication table with rows and columns labeled. The first column lists 300, 60, and 5. The first row lists 40 and 7. The cells contain products of these numbers, with the bottom right cell showing 17155. 
\item This multiplication shows \( 365 \times __________ \)  
\item \( 12,000 \) in the top left box is the answer to \( 300 \times __________ \)  
\item The first column contains \( 300, 60, \) and \( 5 \) because __________  
\item \( 2820 \) is written across from \( 60 \) because __________  
\item The answer \( 17155 \) is calculated by __________  
\item Show by estimating that the answer is sensible: __________  
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
a) Answers will vary based on the values filled in.  
b) Answers will vary based on the values filled in.  
c) Answers will vary based on the values filled in.  
d) Answers will vary based on the values filled in.  
e) \( 4256 \)  
f) \( 41.3 \)  
g) \( 365 \times 47 = 17155 \)  
h) \( 300 \times 40 = 12000 \)  
i) The first column lists numbers that can be multiplied by the numbers in the first row.  
j) \( 2820 \) is the product of \( 60 \times 47 \).  
k) \( 17155 \) is calculated by adding the products of the corresponding row and column.  
l) Estimating \( 365 \) as \( 400 \) and \( 47 \) as \( 50 \) gives \( 400 \times 50 = 20000 \), which is sensible.


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Missing Number Questions) D 1 (With Illustration)

\[
2 + q = 11
\]

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Fill in the blank: \( 5 + q = 10 \)
\item Fill in the blank: \( q - 3 = 2 \)
\item Fill in the blank: \( 8 + q = 15 \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A number line from 0 to 15 with a red dot at 11, indicating the answer. Below it, a grid with empty boxes for equations to be filled in. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Multiplication Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

What is \( 7 \times 6 \)?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is 42.

60 \div 5 = 12

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is 12.

What is \( 18 \times 4 \)?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is \( 72 \).

\subsection{Answers}
The quotient is 6 and the remainder is 2.

6 &   &   &   &   \\
\hline
7 &   &   &   &   \\
\hline
8 &   &   &   &   \\
\hline
9 &   &   &   &   \\
\hline
10 &   &   &   &   \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Time Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

In a 4 x 100 m relay race, the four runners' times are 13.46s, 14.55s, 12.52s, and 19.01s. What is the total time for the race?

\subsection{Answers}
The total time for the race is 59.54 seconds.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Money Transactions) D 6 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

You buy a DVD and a game. How much do you spend in total? 

You buy a CD and a DVD. You pay with a $50 note. How much change do you receive?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How much do you spend in total on the DVD and the game?
\item How much change do you receive after buying a CD and a DVD with a $50 note?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Images of a DVD, a game, a CD, and a $50 note, illustrating the transactions and calculations needed. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Multiplication Completion, Estimation Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Complete these empty boxes to calculate \( 523 \times 47 \):

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Value} & \text{Product} \\
\hline
500 & 20000 \\
\hline
140 & 940 \\
\hline
3 & 21 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

Show by estimating that the answer is sensible:

Estimate \( 523 \) as \( 500 \) and \( 47 \) as \( 50 \). Calculate \( 500 \times 50 \) to check if the answer is reasonable.

\subsection{Answers}
The estimated product is \( 25000 \), which is close to the actual product.


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Your friend does not understand how to carry out column multiplication. Complete the sentences below to explain it to them:

\[
\begin{array}{c}
352 \\
\times 63 \\
\hline
21120 \quad (352 \times \underline{\hspace{1cm}}) \\
1056 \quad (352 \times \underline{\hspace{1cm}}) \\
\hline
22176 \\
\end{array}
\]

21120 is the answer to \underline{\hspace{1cm}}.

1056 is the answer to \underline{\hspace{1cm}}.

I get 22176 by \underline{\hspace{1cm}}.


(Mathematics) (Grid Multiplication, Estimation Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Calculate \( 426 \times 82 \) using the grid below:

\begin{equation*}
426 \times 82 = ?
\end{equation*}

Show by estimating that the answer is sensible:

\subsection{Answers}
The estimated answer is \( 400 \times 80 = 32000 \), which is close to the actual answer.

\begin{enumerate}
\item All the sides of a square are the same length.  
\item A pyramid has 5 vertices.  
\item A pentagon has 6 straight sides and 6 vertices.  
\item Cubes have six square faces.  
\item All shapes with three straight sides are called triangles.  
\item A sphere has no vertices.  
\item All shapes with five straight sides are called hexagons.  
\item Cylinders have 4 circular faces.  
\item Cuboids have six rectangular faces.  
\item All shapes with six straight sides are called pentagons.  
\item Cones have one vertex.  
\end{enumerate}

Choose two incorrect sentences. Re-write them to make them correct.

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|}

\hline

\text{Manchester City} & 53,000 \\
\text{Liverpool} & 54,000 \\
\text{Everton} & 39,000 \\
\text{Newcastle United} & 52,000 \\
\text{Sunderland} & 40,000 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

\item What is the total attendance for these eight clubs?
\item What is the difference in attendance between Manchester United and Manchester City?
\item What is the difference in attendance between Liverpool and Everton?
\item What is the difference in attendance between Newcastle United and Sunderland?
\item What is the difference in attendance between the Manchester clubs (United and City) and the Liverpool and Everton clubs?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Shading and Observation Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the first number you chose?
\item What are the numbers you shaded in red and blue?
\item What pattern do you notice in the numbers you shaded?
\end{enumerate}

\item Write down a number sentence that adds 500 to 400.

(Mathematics) (Group Activity) D 5 (With Illustration)

Think of a 4-digit number. Write your number where no one can see it. Choose one friend to go first. Ask them questions about their number. They can only answer ‘yes’ or ‘no’. Try to ask questions to find the answer as quickly as possible. Good questions to ask are: 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Does it round up?
\item Is it an odd number?
\item Is it a multiple of 10?
\item Is it greater than 4500?
\end{enumerate}

Your group can ask up to 20 questions.

[STRDGM] A grid layout with a list of questions and spaces for answers. The grid is light blue with faint lines. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Cost Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

Sam wants to buy a pair of jeans. Before the sale, the jeans cost $50. In the sale, the jeans are reduced by 20\%. How much do they cost now?

\subsection{Answers}
The jeans now cost $40. 

[STRDGM] A visual showing the original price of the jeans ($50) and the calculation for the 20\% discount, which is $10, leading to the sale price of $40. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Problem Solving) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

There were 680 people at a carnival. Half of the people were children. 25\% of the children were girls. The other children were boys. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many girls were at the carnival?
\item How many boys were at the carnival?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Price Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

Jeans cost \$45 before a sale. In the sale, there is a 20\% discount. What is the new price of the jeans?

\subsection{Answers}
The new price of the jeans is \$36.

(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank) D 2 (With Answer)

Complete the sentences using two or four.  

\_\_\_\_ halves make a whole.  

\_\_\_\_ quarters make a whole.  

\_\_\_\_ quarters are the same as a half.  

\subsection{Answers}  
2 halves make a whole.  
4 quarters make a whole.  
2 quarters are the same as a half.

(Mathematics) (Loop Card Questions, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Who is \( 24 + 13 \)?  

I am 42  

Who is \( 98 - 23 \)?  

I am 75  

Who is \( 6 \times 14 \)?  

I am 84  

Who is \( 120 \div 6 \)?  

I am 20  

Who is \( 19 + 57 \)?  

I am 76  

Who is \( 136 - 23 \)?  

I am 113  

Who is \( 9 \times 18 \)?  

I am 162  

Who is \( 100 \div 4 \)?  

I am 25  

Who is \( 2.8 + 17 \)?  

I am 19.8  

Who is \( 5.5 - 2.3 \)?  

I am 3.2  

Who is \( 0.5 \times 7 \)?  

I am 3.5  

Who is \( 180 \div 4 \)?  

I am 45  

Who is \( 115 + 76 \)?  

I am 191  

Who is \( 89 - 6 \)?  

I am 83  

Who is \( 10 \times 2.7 \)?  

I am 27  

Who is \( 66 \div 3 \)?  

I am 22  

Who is \( 1.56 + 2.33 \)?  

I am 3.84  

Who is \( 15.5 - 10.5 \)?  

I am 5  

Who is \( 100 \times 1.37 \)?  

I am 137  

Who is \( 8 \div 16 \)?

(Mathematics) (Table Completion, Arithmetic Exercise) D 4 (With Illustration)

Complete the table with division examples and remainders.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Number} & \textbf{Divided by 4} & \textbf{Divided by 5} & \textbf{Divided by 6} \\
\hline
31 & 7 R3 & 6 R1 & 5 R1 \\
32 & 8 R0 & 6 R2 & 5 R2 \\
33 & 8 R1 & 6 R3 & 5 R3 \\
34 & 8 R2 & 6 R4 & 5 R4 \\
35 & 8 R3 & 7 R0 & 5 R5 \\
36 & 9 R0 & 7 R1 & 6 R0 \\
37 & 9 R1 & 7 R2 & 6 R1 \\
38 & 9 R2 & 7 R3 & 6 R2 \\
39 & 9 R3 & 7 R4 & 6 R3 \\
40 & 10 R0 & 8 R0 & 6 R4 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Multi-part) D 5 (With Answer)

1. Levi went apple picking. He began at 14:20. He picked apples for 2 hours and 25 minutes. What time did he finish? Levi finished at ______________.

\subsection{Answers}
Levi finished at 16:45.

2. Kieron spent 2 hours and 5 minutes at the gym. He left the gym at 18:20. When did he arrive at the gym? Kieron got there at ______________.

\subsection{Answers}
Kieron got there at 16:15.

3. The twins went to the park. They arrived at 15:50 and left at 17:35. How long were they at the park? The twins were at the park for ______________.

\subsection{Answers}
The twins were at the park for 1 hour and 45 minutes.

4. Carrie and Mona left home to go to school at 07:15. They spent the day working hard. They got home at 16:25. How long were they away from home? Carrie and Mona were away from home for ______________.

\subsection{Answers}
Carrie and Mona were away from home for 9 hours and 10 minutes.

5. Adam and Chris worked in the garden. They started at 14:25. Adam finished at 16:10. Chris continued working for another hour and 10 minutes. For how long was Chris working in the garden? Chris was working in the garden for ______________.

\subsection{Answers}
Chris was working in the garden for 1 hour and 10 minutes.


(Mathematics) (Activity, Card Activity) D 5 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Work with a partner. Pick three digit cards. Make a time using your cards. Use one card to represent the hour number and two cards to represent the minutes. Draw the time on the first analogue clock and write the 12-hour digital time underneath. Is it a morning or an afternoon time? Write a.m. or p.m. beside the time.

For example: Cards picked: 5 9

Digital time: 9:45

Repeat the activity three times, choosing a new set of three cards each time.

Cards picked: ______________

Cards picked: ______________

Cards picked: ______________

[STRDGM] An image of an analogue clock showing the time 9:45 with the hour hand slightly past 9 and the minute hand pointing at 9. Below the clock, the digital time reads "Digital time: 9:45" and a note states "It is morning so the time is 9:45 a.m." [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Ingredient Calculation, Word Problem) D 4 (Multi-part)

You have the following recipes:

1. Spicy Lentil Soup for 2 people: 1 onion, 2 large carrots, 150 g red lentils, 1 liter vegetable stock.
2. Butter Chicken Curry for 4 people: 20 g butter, 1 large onion, chopped, 4 teaspoons curry powder, 4 chicken breasts, cubed, 6 fresh tomatoes, peeled and chopped, 150 ml tinned tomatoes.
3. Chocolate Ice-cream for 6 people: 120 g dark chocolate, in pieces, 300 ml milk, 90 g sugar, 3 egg yolks.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many onions are needed to make Spicy Lentil Soup for 4 people?
\item If you want to make Butter Chicken Curry for 8 people, how much butter is required?
\item How much dark chocolate is needed to make Chocolate Ice-cream for 12 people?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Division Exercise, Word Problem) D 4 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Create 10 different division calculations that each result in the answer of 6. Use the following words in your calculations: apples, cookies, and books.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item If you have 12 apples and you divide them equally among 2 friends, how many apples does each friend get?
\item If you have 30 cookies and you share them equally among 5 people, how many cookies does each person receive?
\item If you have 36 books and you want to place them in 6 boxes equally, how many books will be in each box?
\item If you have 24 oranges and you divide them among 4 baskets, how many oranges will be in each basket?
\item If you have 60 candies and you distribute them to 10 children, how many candies does each child get?
\item If you have 18 pencils and you give them to 3 students equally, how many pencils does each student receive?
\item If you have 48 marbles and you want to put them into 8 bags, how many marbles will be in each bag?
\item If you have 54 stickers and you share them with 9 friends, how many stickers does each friend get?
\item If you have 72 grapes and you divide them into 12 bowls, how many grapes will be in each bowl?
\item If you have 42 toy cars and you want to distribute them among 7 children, how many toy cars will each child receive?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A grid layout for calculations showing each division problem clearly. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise, Distributive Law) D 6 (Multi-part)

Use the distributive law to make these calculations easier to work out: 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 46 \times 8 = (40 + 6) \times 8 = (40 \times 8) + (6 \times 8) = 320 + 48 = 368 \)
\item \( 27 \times 6 = (20 + 7) \times 6 = (20 \times 6) + (7 \times 6) = 120 + 42 = 162 \)
\item \( 38 \times 5 = (30 + 8) \times 5 = (30 \times 5) + (8 \times 5) = 150 + 40 = 190 \)
\item \( 58 \times 7 = (50 + 8) \times 7 = (50 \times 7) + (8 \times 7) = 350 + 56 = 406 \)
\item \( 62 \times 9 = (60 + 2) \times 9 = (60 \times 9) + (2 \times 9) = 540 + 18 = 558 \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] List of multiplication problems to apply the distributive law. [STPDGM]

\item Think of a number. Multiply by 3. Add 9. Divide by 3. Subtract 2. Your answer is your start number.
\item Make up a number puzzle like the ones above. Give your puzzle to your friends to try.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Multi-part) D 3 (With Answer)

(a) What number is 3000 more than 3250? 

(b) What number is 200 less than 45,603? 

(c) What number is 1 more than 4999? 

(d) What number is 10 less than 2019? 

\subsection{Answers}
(a) 6250

(b) 45,403

(c) 5000

(d) 2009

(Mathematics) (Measurement Activity, Estimation Exercise) D 3 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

Work with your friends.  

Get a measuring tape from your teacher.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Estimate the length of your classroom.  
Then measure the length with the measuring tape.  
\item Estimate how far you can walk in 5 steps.  
Then measure the distance with the measuring tape.  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A two-part activity where students first estimate and then measure lengths, with a table for recording estimates and measurements. The table should have columns for "Activity", "Estimated Length", and "Measured Length". [STPDGM]

    \item Bear: 9 kg 950 g
    \item Monkey: 9 kg 95 g
    \item Crocodile: 9 kg 905 g
    \item Bird: 9 kg 59 g
    \item Elephant: 9 kg 590 g
    \item Rabbit: 9 kg 905 g
    \item Tiger: 9 kg 950 g
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
    \item 9095 g
    \item 9905 g
    \item 9950 g
    \item 9590 g
    \item 9059 g
\end{itemize}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Addition Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

Mrs. Li bought 3 bags of pears. There were 4 pears in each bag. How many pears did she buy altogether?

\subsection{Answers}
She bought 12 pears altogether.

[STRDGM] A visual representation of 3 bags, each containing 4 pears. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Division Exercise) D 3 (With Answer, Multi-part)

5 children share 40 rambutan equally. How many rambutan does each child get?

\subsection{Answers}
Each child gets 8 rambutan.

[STRDGM] A visual of 5 children with a total of 40 rambutan divided among them, illustrating equal sharing. [STPDGM]

\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

Mingli earned \$45 in 5 days. He earned the same amount each day. How much did he earn a day?

\subsection{Answers}
Mingli earned \$9 a day.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

A tailor made 8 dresses. He used 3 m of cloth for each dress. How much cloth did he use in all?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Total Cloth Used} = \text{Number of Dresses} \times \text{Cloth per Dress} = 8 \times 3
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of 8 dresses, each labeled with "3 m" of cloth used, and a total amount of cloth usage displayed as "24 m". [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

Mr. Wu bought 6 tubs of ice cream. Each tub contained 2 litres of ice cream. How many litres of ice cream did he buy?

\subsection{Answers}
He bought 12 litres of ice cream.

[STRDGM] An illustration of 6 tubs, each labeled with "2 litres", with a total volume of "12 litres" indicated at the bottom. [STPDGM]

Divide 12 birds into groups of 4. How many groups are there?  

\begin{equation*}
12 \div 4 = 
\end{equation*}

There are \_\_\_\_\_\_ groups.  

\subsection{Answers}
There are 3 groups.

\item How many pages did Meiling read in total over the 4 days?
\item How many pages are there in the book?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Money and Cost) D 3 (With Illustration)

Rani had \$47. After paying for 3 kg of prawns, she had \$20 left. Find the cost of 1 kg of prawns.

\begin{equation*}
\text{Cost of prawns} = \text{Initial amount} - \text{Remaining amount}
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A horizontal bar showing the initial amount of \$47, a segment representing the cost of prawns, and a segment showing the remaining \$20. [STPDGM]

\item What is the length of each piece of rope?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Meilin made 5 bows. She used 75 cm of ribbon for each bow. How many centimetres of ribbon did she use altogether?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Total Ribbon Used} = \text{Number of Bows} \times \text{Ribbon per Bow}
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of 5 bows, each with a ribbon length of 75 cm, with a measuring tape showing the total length of ribbon used. [STPDGM]

\text{Total Savings} = \text{Monthly Savings} \times \text{Number of Months}
\end{equation*}

(Mathematics) (Multiplication Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

Multiply.

\begin{align*}
12 \times 4 &= A \\
21 \times 4 &= R \\
34 \times 2 &= E \\
32 \times 4 &= S \\
51 \times 5 &= R \\
92 \times 4 &= T \\
84 \times 2 &= U \\
72 \times 4 &= E \\
\end{align*}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{align*}
A &= 48 \\
R &= 84 \\
E &= 68 \\
S &= 128 \\
R &= 255 \\
T &= 368 \\
U &= 168 \\
E &= 288 \\
\end{align*}

[STRDGM] Eight sailboat illustrations, each with a multiplication equation written inside the sail. The letters A, R, E, S, R, T, U, and E are positioned below the boats, corresponding to the answers of the equations. [STPDGM]

\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

There were 200 people in a hall. The number of people later increased to 500. Express the increase in the number of people as a percentage of the original number of people.

\subsection{Answers}
The increase in the number of people is \( \frac{500 - 200}{200} \times 100\% = 150\% \).

[STRDGM] A diagram showing two groups: one with 200 people (original) and another with 500 people (after increase), with an arrow indicating the increase. [STPDGM]

\item Fill in the blank: \( 6 - 4 = \_\_\_ \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A cartoon boy is smiling and speaking, standing next to 6 bottles of milk arranged in a row. The bottles are labeled and clearly visible. [STPDGM]

\item \( 5 - 2 = \)  
\item \( 25 - 2 = \)

\item 8

\item 29

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

The ratio of the number of John's marbles to the number of Aaron's marbles is \( 8 : 15 \). Aaron has 105 more marbles than John. If Aaron gives 20 of his marbles to John, what will be the new ratio of the number of John's marbles to the number of Aaron's marbles?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many marbles does John have initially?
\item How many marbles does Aaron have initially?
\item What will be the new ratio of John's marbles to Aaron's marbles after the transfer?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing two groups of marbles: one labeled "John's Marbles" with a smaller number, and another labeled "Aaron's Marbles" with a larger number, indicating the initial ratio and the transfer of 20 marbles from Aaron to John. [STPDGM]

The ratio of the amount of Eric's money to the amount of Oliver's money was \( 3 : 7 \). Eric had $120 less than Oliver. After Oliver gave $6 to Eric, what was the new ratio of the amount of Eric's money to the amount of Oliver's money?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What were the initial amounts of money that Eric and Oliver had?
\item What is the new ratio of the amount of Eric's money to the amount of Oliver's money after the transfer?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating two piles of money: one labeled "Eric's Money" with the initial amount and the other labeled "Oliver's Money" with the initial amount, showing the transfer of $6 from Oliver to Eric. [STPDGM]

The ratio of the number of students on Bus A to the number of students on Bus B was \( 5 : 9 \). Bus A had 20 fewer students than Bus B. Later, 15 students transferred from Bus B to Bus A. Find the new ratio of the number of students on Bus A to the number of students on Bus B.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many students were initially on Bus A and Bus B?
\item What is the new ratio of the number of students on Bus A to the number of students on Bus B after the transfer?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

A platoon of soldiers marched at an average speed of 20 \(\text{m/min}\) for 16 minutes. What was the distance they marched?

\subsection{Answers}
The distance marched is 320 meters.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

A farmer pushed a cart at an average speed of 28 \(\text{cm/s}\) for 50 seconds. How many metres did the cart travel?

\subsection{Answers}
The cart traveled 14 metres. 

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting a farmer pushing a cart along a path, with indicators of speed (28 cm/s) and time elapsed (50 seconds). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

An aeroplane flew at an average speed of 255 \(\text{km/h}\) for 9 hours. What was the distance it travelled?

\subsection{Answers}
The distance travelled is \( 255 \, \text{km/h} \times 9 \, \text{h} = 2295 \, \text{km}.\)

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Average Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

Douglas ran 150 \text{ m} in 25 \text{ seconds}. Find his average speed in \text{ m/s}.

\subsection{Answers}
His average speed is 6 \text{ m/s}.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Average Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

Lisa walked 1176 cm in 42 seconds. What was her average speed in cm/s?

\subsection{Answers}
Her average speed is \( \frac{1176 \text{ cm}}{42 \text{ s}} = 28 \text{ cm/s} \).

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting a person walking with a stopwatch showing 42 seconds and a distance marker at 1176 centimeters. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Average Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

A train travelled 1708 km in 7 hours. Find its average speed in km/h.

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed is \( \frac{1708 \text{ km}}{7 \text{ hours}} = 243.43 \text{ km/h} \).

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating a train on a railway track with a clock indicating 7 hours and a distance marker at 1708 kilometers. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

Towns A and B were 270 km apart. Roger left Town A at 8:05 a.m. and reached Town B at 10:35 a.m. If he had decreased his average speed by 18 km/h, how much later would he have reached Town B?

[STRDGM] A timeline showing Roger's departure at 8:05 a.m. from Town A and arrival at 10:35 a.m. at Town B, with a distance of 270 km between Town A and Town B. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance and Time Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Rose and Lucy set off from Town C to Town D at the same time. The two towns were 640 km apart. After 8 hours, Rose reached Town D, while Lucy was still 128 km away from Town D. If Lucy continued at the same average speed, how much longer did she take than Rose to reach Town D?

\subsection{Answers}
Lucy took 1 hour longer than Rose to reach Town D.

(Mathematics) (Addition Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

34 + 6 = 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Draw 34 squares in a row and shade them to represent the number 34.
\item Next to it, draw 6 additional squares and shade them to represent the number 6.
\item Count the total number of shaded squares.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The image features multiple columns of squares, with 34 squares shaded in one column and 6 squares shaded in another column. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Addition Exercise, Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (Multi-part, With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \(3\) tens + \(5\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(30 + 50 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(2\) tens + \(3\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(20 + 30 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(1\) ten + \(5\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(10 + 50 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(3\) tens + \(4\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(30 + 40 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(6\) tens + \(2\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(60 + 20 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(2\) tens + \(7\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(20 + 70 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(3\) tens + \(3\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(30 + 30 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(8\) tens + \(1\) ten = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(80 + 10 = \_\_\_\)  

\item \(5\) tens + \(4\) tens = \_\_\_ tens  
\item \(50 + 40 = \_\_\_\)  
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Estimation Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Nancy left Town M at 6:20 p.m. and reached Town N at 7:50 p.m. Her average speed for the journey was 70 km/h. If she had travelled at an average speed of 50 km/h, how much longer would she take to reach Town N?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the time taken for the journey at 70 km/h.
\item Calculate the distance between Town M and Town N.
\item Determine how long it would take to travel the same distance at 50 km/h.
\item How much longer would she take to reach Town N at 50 km/h compared to 70 km/h?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A timeline showing Nancy's departure at 6:20 p.m. and arrival at 7:50 p.m., with the distances and speeds indicated (70 km/h and 50 km/h). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Estimation Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate John's average speed during his trip from City P to City Q.
\item Determine the time it would take for John to travel from City P to City Q if he had increased his average speed by 20 km/h.
\item How much earlier would he have reached City Q with the increased speed?
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

A lorry driver took 3 hours to travel from a port to a warehouse. For the first \( \frac{6}{11} \) of the journey, he travelled at an average speed of 60 km/h. If his average speed for the whole journey was 55 km/h, find his average speed for the remaining journey.

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed for the remaining journey is 45 km/h.

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a lorry traveling from a port to a warehouse, with segments labeled for the first \( \frac{6}{11} \) of the journey at 60 km/h and the remaining journey at 45 km/h. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Adrian took 5 hours to travel from his village to a city. His average speed for the whole journey was 72 km/h. For the first \( \frac{5}{8} \) of the journey, he travelled at an average speed of 75 km/h. What was his average speed for the rest of the journey?

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed for the rest of the journey is 60 km/h.

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating Adrian's journey from his village to a city, with sections marked for the first \( \frac{5}{8} \) of the journey showing a speed of 75 km/h, and the remaining distance showing a speed of 60 km/h. [STPDGM]

\[

\subsection{Answers}
The number of birds left is \( z \).

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance and Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

A ship sailed 1050 km at an average speed of 75 km/h. How long did it sail?

\subsection{Answers}
The time taken to sail is 14 hours.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance and Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

Gary drove at an average speed of 84 km/h from Town A to Town B. If the two towns were 273 km apart, find the time he took.

\subsection{Answers}
The time taken is \( \frac{273 \text{ km}}{84 \text{ km/h}} = 3.25 \text{ hours} \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance and Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

Jack drove from City X to City Y at an average speed of 60 \text{ km/h}. The two cities were 570 \text{ km} apart. What was the time taken?

\subsection{Answers}
The time taken is 9.5 hours.

Calvin and Bob set off from City X to City Y at 5:05 p.m. Calvin travelled at an average speed of 72 km/h and reached City Y at 6:35 p.m. If Bob's average speed was 60 km/h, at what time did he reach City Y?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the time it took Calvin to travel from City X to City Y.
\item Using Bob's average speed, calculate the time it took him to travel the same distance.
\item Determine the time Bob reached City Y.
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Comparison Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration)

Oliver and Paul started from Town M towards Town N at 10:40 a.m. Towns M and N were 360 km apart. If Oliver reached Town N at 3:10 p.m. and Paul reached Town N 18 minutes later, find the difference in their average speeds.

\subsection{Answers}
Oliver's average speed is 72 km/h, and Paul's average speed is 64 km/h. The difference in their average speeds is 8 km/h.

[STRDGM] A timeline showing the departure time of 10:40 a.m. for both Oliver and Paul, with Oliver's arrival at 3:10 p.m. and Paul's arrival at 3:28 p.m. A distance of 360 km between Town M and Town N is indicated. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

(a) Express the sum of money he had at first in terms of \( c \).  

(b) If \( c = 6 \), find the sum of money he had at first.  

(c) If \( c = 27 \), find the sum of money he had at first.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Let the sum of money he had at first be represented as \( x \). If he spent $13, then the remaining amount is \( c \). Therefore, the equation can be expressed as:
\[
x - 13 = c
\]
Thus, the sum of money he had at first in terms of \( c \) is:
\[
x = c + 13
\]

\item If \( c = 6 \), substituting into the equation gives:
\[
x = 6 + 13 = 19
\]

\item If \( c = 27 \), substituting into the equation gives:
\[
x = 27 + 13 = 40
\]
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing Alfred with an initial amount of money \( x \), a subtraction of $13, and a remaining amount represented as \( c \). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Weight Comparison) D 6 (Multi-part)

(a) Express the amount of weights Paul can carry in terms of \( d \).  

(b) If \( d = 3 \), find the amount of weights Paul can carry.  

(c) If \( d = 6 \), find the amount of weights Paul can carry.  

\begin{equation*}
\text{Let the weight Jeremy can carry be } 8 \text{ kg. Then, Paul can carry } (8 + d) \text{ kg.}
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating Jeremy carrying 8 kg and Paul carrying \( (8 + d) \) kg, with weights labeled accordingly. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

Calvin and Jerry are standing next to each other with a total of 90 marbles between them. Jerry has a certain number of marbles represented by \( c \), and Calvin has more marbles than Jerry.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the number of marbles Calvin has more than Jerry in terms of \( c \).
\item If \( c = 16 \), find the number of marbles Calvin has more than Jerry.
\item If \( c = 25 \), find the number of marbles Calvin has more than Jerry.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Two people, Jerry and Calvin, are standing next to each other with a total of 90 marbles between them. Jerry has \( c \) marbles, and Calvin has \( 90 - c \) marbles. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

There are \(\frac{3}{5}\) as many cows as sheep on a farm. If there are 240 cows and sheep altogether, how many more sheep than cows are there?

\subsection{Answers}
There are 60 more sheep than cows.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Jason sold \(\frac{3}{10}\) as many pens as Mike. If Jason sold 210 fewer pens than Mike, how many pens did they sell altogether?

\subsection{Answers}
Let \( x \) be the number of pens Mike sold. Then, Jason sold \(\frac{3}{10}x\) pens. According to the problem, we have the equation:

\[
\frac{3}{10}x = x - 210
\]

Solving for \( x \):

\[
\frac{3}{10}x + 210 = x
\]
\[
210 = x - \frac{3}{10}x
\]
\[
210 = \frac{7}{10}x
\]
\[
x = 210 \times \frac{10}{7} = 300
\]

So, Mike sold 300 pens, and Jason sold:

\[
\frac{3}{10} \times 300 = 90
\]

Altogether, they sold:

\[
300 + 90 = 390 \text{ pens.}
\]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Rachel bought \(\frac{5}{12}\) as many stamps as Michelle. Michelle bought 420 more stamps than Rachel. How many stamps did Michelle buy?

\subsection{Answers}
Michelle bought 840 stamps.

\item \( 9 + 8 \)
\item \( 6 + 5 \)
\item \( 8 + 7 \)
\item \( 7 + 7 \)
\item \( 6 + 8 \)
\item \( 8 + 9 \)
\item \( 7 + 5 \)
\item \( 8 + 5 \)

(Mathematics) (Measurement Conversion) D 5 (With Answer)

Find the equivalent measures.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.4 \) m = ________ cm
\item \( 1.25 \) kg = ______ kg ______ g 
\item \( 305 \) ml = ________ L
\item \( 0.75 \) ft = ________ in. 
\item \( 6.25 \) lb = _____ lb _____ oz 
\item \( 3.25 \) gal = ______ gal _____ c 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 40 \) cm 
\item \( 1 \) kg \( 250 \) g 
\item \( 0.305 \) L 
\item \( 9 \) in. 
\item \( 6 \) lb \( 4 \) oz 
\item \( 3 \) gal \( 4 \) c 
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Percentage Conversion, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Express each as a percentage. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.47 \) 
\item \( \frac{6}{15} \) 
\item \( 215 \) out of \( 500 \) 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 47\% \) 
\item \( 40\% \) 
\item \( 43\% \) 
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Percentage to Decimal and Fraction Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Express each percentage as a decimal and as a fraction in its simplest form.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 85\% \)  Decimal: _________  Fraction: __________ 
\item \( 16\% \)  Decimal: _________  Fraction: __________ 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.85 \), \( \frac{17}{20} \) 
\item \( 0.16 \), \( \frac{4}{25} \) 
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

Find \( 32\% \) of \( \$96 \).

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is \( \$30.72 \).


(Mathematics) (Average Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

Find the average of \( 21.4 \), \( 18.2 \), and \( 65.7 \). 

\subsection{Answers}
The average is \( 35.1 \).


(Mathematics) (Average with Missing Value) D 5 (With Answer)

Fill in the blank: The average of \( 42 \), \( 36 \), \( x \), and \( 25 \) is \( 30 \). 

\subsection{Answers}
\[ x = 17 \]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

John had \( \$75 \). He spent \( \$15 \) on a book. What percentage of his money does he have left?

\subsection{Answers}
He has \( 80\% \) of his money left.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Discount Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

The normal price of a camera was \( \$76 \). At a sale, it was sold at a discount of \( 15\% \). What was the selling price of the camera?

\subsection{Answers}
The selling price of the camera is \( \$64.60 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Average Weight Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

The average weight of \( 3 \) packages is \( 2 \) kg \( 750 \) g. The average weight of \( 2 \) of them is \( 3 \) kg \( 200 \) g. Find the weight of the third package. Give your answer in kg and g.

\subsection{Answers}
The weight of the third package is \( 1 \) kg \( 850 \) g.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

In a city, the rate for taxi fare for the first kilometer is \( \$2.60 \) and for every additional kilometer it is \( \$0.80 \). Find the taxi fare for a journey of \( 6.5 \) km.

\subsection{Answers}
The taxi fare is \( \$7.40 \).


(Mathematics) (Angle Calculation, Geometry Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

The following figures are not drawn to scale. Find the unknown marked angle in each. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( ABC \) is a straight line. \( BCD \) is an equilateral triangle.
\item \( ABCD \) is a parallelogram.
\item \( ABC \) is a straight line. \( BCDE \) is a rhombus.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 85° \)
\item \( 32° \)
\item \( 65° \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] 
- (a) A straight line \( ABC \) with \( BCD \) forming an equilateral triangle at point \( B \).
- (b) A parallelogram \( ABCD \).
- (c) A straight line \( ABC \) with \( BCDE \) forming a rhombus at point \( B \).
[STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation with Flow Rate) D 5 (With Answer)

A rectangular tank measures \( 50 \) cm by \( 20 \) cm by \( 33 \) cm. It is to be filled with water from a tap. It takes \( 2 \) minutes to fill it to a height of \( 12 \) cm. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the rate of flow from the tap in liters per minute?
\item How many more minutes will it take to fill the tank?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
(a) \( 6 \) L/min

(b) \( 3.5 \) min

[STRDGM] A rectangular tank with dimensions \( 50 \) cm (length) \( \times \) \( 20 \) cm (width) \( \times \) \( 33 \) cm (height), filled to a height of \( 12 \) cm in \( 2 \) minutes. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

A rectangular container \( 8 \) cm long and \( 9 \) cm wide was filled with water to a depth of \( 6 \) cm. When \( 12 \) marbles of equal size were added to the container, the depth of the water became \( 7.5 \) cm. Find the volume of one marble. 

\subsection{Answers}
The volume of one marble is \( 9 \text{cm}^3 \).


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation of Cubes) D 5 (With Answer)

How many \( 4 \)-cm cubes can fit into a rectangular box that is \( 1 \) m long, \( 0.4 \) m wide, and \( 0.6 \) m high?

\subsection{Answers}
The number of \( 4 \)-cm cubes that can fit into the box is \( 3750 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Money Distribution) D 5 (With Answer)

Sam had \( \$85 \) and John had \( \$220 \). They were each given an equal amount of money. After receiving the money, John had twice as much money as Sam. How much money did each boy receive?

\subsection{Answers}
Each boy received \( \$50 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

\subsection{Answers}
Alice has \( \$227.50 \).


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation in Cubic Inches) D 5 (With Answer)

\subsection{Answers}
The volume is \( 1728 \text{ in}^3 \).

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions Evaluation) D 6 (Multi-part)

Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( w = 5 \).

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( w + 7 = \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions Evaluation, Multi-part) D 6 (With Answer)

Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( x = 12 \).

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 21 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 1 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 35 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 3 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 43 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 6 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 56 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 9 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( 70 - x = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\item \( x - 12 = \_\_\_\_\_\_ \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 21 - 12 = 9 \)
\item \( 12 - 1 = 11 \)
\item \( 35 - 12 = 23 \)
\item \( 12 - 3 = 9 \)
\item \( 43 - 12 = 31 \)
\item \( 12 - 6 = 6 \)
\item \( 56 - 12 = 44 \)
\item \( 12 - 9 = 3 \)
\item \( 70 - 12 = 58 \)
\item \( 12 - 12 = 0 \)
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions Evaluation) D 6 (Multi-part, With Answer)

Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( x = 8 \). (2 marks each)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 3x = \) ______
\item \( \frac{x}{4} = \) ______
\item \( 5x + 5 = \) ______
\item \( 21 - 2x = \) ______
\item \( 7 + \frac{x}{3} = \) ______
\item \( \frac{7x}{2} - 10 = \) ______
\item \( x + \frac{x}{2} = \) ______
\item \( 4x - \frac{7x}{8} = \) ______
\item \( 2x^2 - 14 = \) ______
\item \( \frac{3x}{16} = \) ______
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item 24
\item 2
\item 45
\item 5
\item 11
\item 18
\item 12
\item 25
\item 94
\item 1.5
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions Simplification, Multi-part) D 6 (With Answer)

Simplify each of the following expressions. (2 marks each)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 3a + 6a = \) ______
\item \( 7b - 4b = \) ______
\item \( 5c + c + 2c = \) ______
\item \( 10d - 3d - 7d = \) ______
\item \( 8e - 6e + 9e = \) ______
\item \( 4f + 5f + 2f = \) ______
\item \( 6g + 8 - g = \) ______
\item \( 9h + 4 - 3h - 5h = \) ______
\item \( i + 8 + 12i - 2 = \) ______
\item \( 16 + 14j - 5 - 9j = \) ______
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
1. \( 9a \)  
2. \( 3b \)  
3. \( 8c \)  
4. \( 0 \)  
5. \( 11e \)  
6. \( 11f \)  
7. \( 5g + 8 \)  
8. \( 0 + 4 = 4 \)  
9. \( 13i + 6 \)  
10. \( 7j + 11 \)

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions Evaluation) D 6 (Multi-part, With Answer)

Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( k = 12 \). (2 marks each)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( \frac{k}{3} + k = \) __________
\item \( k - \frac{k}{2} = \) __________
\item \( k - \frac{k}{6} = \) __________
\item \( 2k + \frac{k}{12} = \) __________
\item \( 7k - \frac{k}{2} = \) __________
\item \( 5k + \frac{2k}{3} = \) __________
\item \( 6k - \frac{5k}{2} = \) __________
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item 12 + 12 = 24
\item 12 - 6 = 6
\item 12 - 2 = 10
\item 24 + 1 = 25
\item 84 - 6 = 78
\item 60 + 8 = 68
\item 72 - 30 = 42
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions Evaluation) D 6 (Multi-part, With Answer)

Find the value of each of the following expressions when \( m = 3 \). (2 marks each)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( m^2 + 5 = \) __________
\item \( 14 + m^3 = \) __________
\item \( m^2 - 19 = \) __________
\item \( 16 - m^2 = \) __________
\item \( 4m^3 + 3 = \) __________
\item \( 5m^2 - 7 = \) __________
\item \( 8 + 3m^3 = \) __________
\item \( 100 - 2m^2 = \) __________
\item \( \frac{4m^2}{3} = \) __________
\item \( \frac{5m^3}{9} = \) __________
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 3^2 + 5 = 14 \)
\item \( 14 + 3^3 = 41 \)
\item \( 3^2 - 19 = -10 \)
\item \( 16 - 3^2 = 7 \)
\item \( 4(3^3) + 3 = 111 \)
\item \( 5(3^2) - 7 = 38 \)
\item \( 8 + 3(3^3) = 83 \)
\item \( 100 - 2(3^2) = 82 \)
\item \( \frac{4(3^2)}{3} = 12 \)
\item \( \frac{5(3^3)}{9} = 15 \)
\end{enumerate}

(2) Bottle B weighs ____ units.  

(3) Bottle ____ is the lightest.  

(4) Bottle ____ is the heaviest.  

(5) Bottle A is lighter than Bottle ____.  

[STRDGM] Three bottles labeled A, B, and C are shown on a balance scale, with different weights represented by stacks of circles, squares, and triangles. The weights of the shapes indicate the relative weights of the bottles. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Express 600 ml as a percentage of 4 €.

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage is 15000\%.


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Express 350 ml as a percentage of 2.5 €.

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage is \( \frac{350 \, \text{ml}}{2.5 \, €} \times 100\% = 14000\% \).


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Express 210 \, \text{ml} as a percentage of 7 \, \text{€}.

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage is \( \frac{210 \, \text{ml}}{7 \, \text{€}} \times 100\% = 3000\% \).


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Express 60 \,€ as a percentage of 50 \,c.

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage is 120%.

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage is \( 290\% \).

Express \( 70 \, c \) as a percentage of \( 25 \, c \).

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage is \( 280\% \).

\subsection{Answers}

Write the numbers corresponding to the words.

\begin{itemize}
    \item twenty-seven: \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\

(Mathematics) (Counting Exercise, Addition Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 3 + 2 = [ ] \)
\item \( 8 + 1 = [ ] \)
\item \( 4 + 2 = [ ] \)
\item \( 7 + 3 = [ ] \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Four illustrations showing a character running along a number line. Each illustration highlights a starting number and the next numbers to count on for addition. The first shows numbers 3 to 5, the second shows 8 to 9, the third shows 4 to 6, and the fourth shows 7 to 10. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration)

Joyce mixed orange syrup with water in the ratio \( 2 : 7 \) to make \( 18 \) litres of orange drink. How many litres of orange syrup did she use?

[STRDGM] A diagram showing two containers: one labeled "Orange Syrup" with a portion marked \( 2 \), and another labeled "Water" with a portion marked \( 7 \), both leading to a larger container labeled "Orange Drink" with a total of \( 18 \) litres. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration)

Gary mixed Grade A rice and Grade B rice in the ratio \( 5 : 3 \) to get \( 24 \, \text{kg} \) of Grade C rice. How many kilograms of Grade A rice did he use?

\subsection{Answers}
Gary used \( 15 \, \text{kg} \) of Grade A rice.

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating two bags: one labeled "Grade A Rice" with a portion marked \( 5 \), and another labeled "Grade B Rice" with a portion marked \( 3 \), leading to a larger bag labeled "Grade C Rice" with a total weight of \( 24 \, \text{kg} \). [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio and Proportion Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

A piece of string was cut into two pieces in the ratio \( 4 : 11 \). If the longer piece of string was \( 44 \, \text{cm} \) long, find the original length of the piece of string.

\subsection{Answers}
The original length of the piece of string is \( 88 \, \text{cm} \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Andrew and Martin shared 48 balloons in the ratio 3 : 13. How many more balloons did Martin get than Andrew?

\subsection{Answers}
Martin got 36 more balloons than Andrew.

\subsection{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many boys were there originally in the club?
\item What is the new number of girls after 30 girls leave?
\item What is the new ratio of boys to girls?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a school club with boys represented by blue circles and girls represented by pink circles, with a total of 330 pink circles for girls and a calculated number of blue circles for boys. After 30 pink circles are removed, the new count of pink circles is shown. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Money Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

The ratio of the amount of Andrew's money to the amount of Paul's money was \( 5 : 3 \). Andrew had $30 more than Paul. Later, Andrew spent $15 on a book. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What were the initial amounts of money that Andrew and Paul had?
\item What is the new ratio of the amount of Andrew's money to the amount of Paul's money after Andrew spent $15?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating two stacks of money, one for Andrew labeled with his initial amount and one for Paul labeled with his initial amount, along with a note indicating the $15 deduction from Andrew's stack. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

The ratio of the number of Cynthia's posters to the number of Laura's posters was \( 3 : 4 \). Cynthia had 24 fewer posters than Laura. Later, Laura gave 36 of her posters away to her brother. Find the new ratio of the number of Cynthia's posters to the number of Laura's posters.

\subsection{Answers}
Let the number of Cynthia's posters be \( 3x \) and Laura's posters be \( 4x \). According to the problem, we have:
\[
3x = 4x - 24
\]
Solving for \( x \):
\[
x = 24
\]
Thus, Cynthia has \( 3 \times 24 = 72 \) posters and Laura has \( 4 \times 24 = 96 \) posters. After Laura gives away 36 posters, she has \( 96 - 36 = 60 \) posters. The new ratio of Cynthia's posters to Laura's posters is:
\[
\frac{72}{60} = \frac{12}{10} = \frac{6}{5}
\]
The new ratio is \( 6 : 5 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Money Calculation) D 1 (With Answer)

Ian paid 80¢ for the pair of scissors. If the scissors cost 120¢, how much money did he get back?

\subsection{Answers}
He got 40¢ back. 

[STRDGM] Image of a pair of scissors next to the text. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Norman weighed 30 kg last year. Now he weighs 42 kg. By what percentage did his weight increase?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage increase in his weight is \( \frac{42 - 30}{30} \times 100 = 40\% \). 

[STRDGM] A scale showing a weight of 30 kg on one side and 42 kg on the other, with an arrow indicating the increase. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Increase Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

There were 1500 viewers at a show on the first day. On the second day, there were 2500 viewers. By what percentage did the number of viewers increase?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage increase in viewers is \( \frac{2500 - 1500}{1500} \times 100\% = \frac{1000}{1500} \times 100\% = 66.67\% \).

[STRDGM] A bar graph comparing 1500 viewers on the first day and 2500 viewers on the second day, with an upward arrow indicating growth. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

The usual price of a television set was \$800. Sarah bought it for \$700 after a discount. How many percent discount did she get?

\subsection{Answers}
The discount percentage is 12.5\%.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Willie took 7 hours to travel from City A to City B. He drove at an average speed of 90 km/h for the first 3 hours and then at an average speed of 55 km/h for the rest of the journey. Find his average speed for the whole journey.

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed for the whole journey is approximately 70.71 km/h.

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a straight road between City A and City B, with a marker indicating the distance covered in the first 3 hours (270 km) and the remaining distance (165 km). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

Joyce and Mary have 420 stickers altogether. If Joyce has 180 stickers, how many per cent fewer stickers does she have than Mary?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Let } M \text{ be the number of stickers Mary has.}
\end{equation*}
\begin{equation*}
M = 420 - 180
\end{equation*}
\begin{equation*}
\text{Percentage fewer stickers Joyce has than Mary} = \left( \frac{M - 180}{M} \right) \times 100
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of two quantities of stickers, one labeled "Joyce: 180" and the other labeled "Mary: 240," with a total labeled "Joyce + Mary: 420," and a percentage calculation shown between them. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Calculation Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Martin travelled from Town P to Town Q at an average speed of 90 km/h for 2 hours. Without stopping, he travelled from Town Q to Town R which were 300 km apart. If his average speed for the whole journey was 80 km/h, what was his average speed from Town Q to Town R?

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed from Town Q to Town R is 60 km/h.

[STRDGM] A diagram showing three towns: Town P, Town Q, and Town R, with distances labeled. An arrow from Town P to Town Q indicates a speed of 90 km/h for 2 hours, and another arrow from Town Q to Town R indicates a speed of 60 km/h. [STPDGM]

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed for the whole journey is \( 60 \) km/h.

Edward jogged at an average speed of 85 \(\text{m/min}\) for 24 minutes. Find the distance he jogged.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

\subsection{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance and Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

Sam drove from Town A to Town B. He covered \( \frac{1}{3} \) of the journey in the first hour and \( \frac{2}{5} \) of the journey in the second hour. He took \( \frac{1}{2} \) hour to cover the remaining 40 km. Find his average speed for the whole journey.

\subsection{Answers}
To find the total distance, let the total distance be \( D \). Then, we have:
\[
\frac{1}{3}D + \frac{2}{5}D + 40 = D
\]
Solving for \( D \):
\[
\frac{5}{15}D + \frac{6}{15}D + 40 = D \\
\frac{11}{15}D + 40 = D \\
40 = D - \frac{11}{15}D \\
40 = \frac{4}{15}D \\
D = 40 \times \frac{15}{4} = 150 \text{ km}
\]

Total time taken:
- First hour: 1 hour
- Second hour: 1 hour
- Last segment: \( \frac{1}{2} \) hour

Total time = \( 1 + 1 + \frac{1}{2} = 2.5 \) hours.

Average speed = \( \frac{\text{Total Distance}}{\text{Total Time}} = \frac{150 \text{ km}}{2.5 \text{ hours}} = 60 \text{ km/h} \).

The average speed for the whole journey is \( 60 \text{ km/h} \).

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a straight line representing the journey from Town A to Town B, divided into three segments: the first segment (1/3 of the journey), the second segment (2/5 of the journey), and the last segment (40 km). Each segment is labeled with the time taken for each part: 1 hour for the first segment, 1 hour for the second segment, and 0.5 hours for the last segment. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance and Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Angela cycled from Village A to Village B. She took 30 minutes to cover \( \frac{3}{10} \) of the journey, 1 hour to cover \( \frac{3}{8} \) of the journey, and 1 hour to cover the remaining 6.5 km. What was her average speed for the whole journey?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the total distance of the journey.
\item Determine Angela's average speed for the entire journey.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a path from Village A to Village B, divided into three segments: the first segment representing \( \frac{3}{10} \) of the journey labeled with "30 minutes", the second segment representing \( \frac{3}{8} \) of the journey labeled with "1 hour", and the last segment representing 6.5 km labeled with "1 hour". [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance and Speed Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

A train travelled from City P to City Q. It covered \( \frac{5}{12} \) of the journey in the first 3 hours, \( \frac{1}{4} \) of the journey in the next hour, and the remaining 180 km in 2 hours. Find its average speed for the whole journey.

\subsection{Answers}
To find the total distance, we first calculate the total journey distance \( D \):
\[
\frac{5}{12}D + \frac{1}{4}D + 180 = D
\]
Converting \( \frac{1}{4}D \) to twelfths gives \( \frac{3}{12}D \):
\[
\frac{5}{12}D + \frac{3}{12}D + 180 = D
\]
\[
\frac{8}{12}D + 180 = D
\]
\[
180 = D - \frac{8}{12}D
\]
\[
180 = \frac{4}{12}D
\]
\[
D = 180 \times 3 = 540 \text{ km}
\]

Now, we calculate the total time taken:
- Time for the first segment: 3 hours
- Time for the second segment: 1 hour
- Time for the third segment: 2 hours

Total time = \( 3 + 1 + 2 = 6 \) hours.

Average speed = \( \frac{\text{Total Distance}}{\text{Total Time}} = \frac{540 \text{ km}}{6 \text{ hours}} = 90 \text{ km/h} \).

Thus, the average speed for the whole journey is 90 km/h.

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating the journey from City P to City Q, divided into three segments: the first segment (5/12 of the journey), the second segment (1/4 of the journey), and the last segment (180 km). Each segment is labeled with the time taken for each part. [STPDGM]

\item \( 10 \, \_\_\_ \, 2 = 8 \)

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Calculation Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

Louis travelled from Town P to Town Q at an average speed of 88 km/h in \( 2 \frac{1}{4} \) hours. He then continued from Town Q to Town R at an average speed of 96 km/h in \( 1 \frac{3}{4} \) hours. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What was the distance from Town P to Town Q?
\item What was the distance from Town Q to Town R?
\item What was his average speed for the whole journey?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A map showing three towns: P, Q, and R, with distances labeled as calculated above and arrows indicating the direction of travel. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Calculation Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Mike drove from Town X to Town Y at an average speed of 76 \(\text{km/h}\) in 5 hours 15 minutes. He continued driving for another \(3 \frac{3}{4}\) hours from Town Y to Town Z. If his average speed for the whole journey was 81 \(\text{km/h}\), find his average speed from Town Y to Town Z.

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed from Town Y to Town Z is 88 \(\text{km/h}\).

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating the route from Town X to Town Y and then to Town Z, with time and speed annotations for each segment. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Calculation Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Nicholas travelled from City K to City L at an average speed of 68 km/h for 4 hours. Without stopping, he travelled from City L to City M which were 160 km apart. If his average speed for the whole journey was 72 km/h, what was his average speed from City L to City M?

\subsection{Answers}
The average speed from City L to City M was 80 km/h.

[STRDGM] A visual representation of the journey from City K to City L and then to City M, with distances of 272 km from K to L and 160 km from L to M, and speeds of 68 km/h and 80 km/h indicated. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

(a) There are ________ monkeys.  

(b) There are ________ bears.  

(c) There are ________ more monkeys than bears.  

(d) There are ________ fewer lions than bears.  

(e) There are ________ animals altogether.  

[STRDGM] The image shows three rows with illustrations of animals: monkeys, lions, and bears. Each row contains a specific number of cartoonish animal faces. The task is to fill in the blanks based on the number of animals depicted. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Multiplication Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Calculate the following:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item \( 8 \times 8 = 64 \)
\item \( 8 \times 8.25 = 66 \)
\item \( 8 \times 8.5 = 68 \)
\item \( 8 \times 8.75 = 70 \)
\item \( 8 \times 9 = 72 \)
\item \( 8 \times 9.125 = 73 \)
\item \( 8 \times 9.5 = 76 \)
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A cartoon bird flying upwards, looking happy. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Jimmy took 5 minutes to swim 560 m. If he continued swimming for another 12 minutes at the same average speed, how much further did he swim?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate Jimmy's average speed in meters per minute.
\item How much further did he swim in the additional 12 minutes?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a swimmer in a pool, with a distance marker at 560 m and a clock indicating 5 minutes, with an arrow extending further to represent additional swimming time. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Speed Calculation Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Ricky set off from Town A at 7:30 a.m. and reached Town B at 8:15 a.m. The two towns were 60 km apart. If he had to reach Town B at 8:06 a.m., at what average speed would he have to travel?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What was Ricky's actual average speed from Town A to Town B?
\item What average speed would he need to travel to arrive at 8:06 a.m.?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A map showing two towns labeled A and B, with a distance of 60 km between them, and clocks indicating the departure time of 7:30 a.m. and the arrival times of 8:15 a.m. and 8:06 a.m. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

\frac{2}{5} of Vivian's stickers is equal to \frac{3}{5} of Laura's stickers. If they have 150 stickers altogether, how many stickers does Vivian have?

\subsection{Answers}
Vivian has 60 stickers.

\(\frac{3}{4}\) of Doreen's storybooks is equal to \(\frac{5}{6}\) of Lisa's storybooks. If Doreen has 180 more storybooks than Lisa, how many storybooks do they have altogether?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many storybooks does Doreen have?
\item How many storybooks does Lisa have?
\item What is the total number of storybooks they have?
\end{enumerate}
