(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

\frac{3}{8} of Ann's money is five times as much as Susan's money. If Ann has \$555 more than Susan, how much money does Ann have?

\subsection{Answers}
Ann has \$1,110.

(Mathematics) (Addition Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

Add and write the answers in the circles for two sets of numbers arranged in a grid format.

The first grid contains three rows and three columns with the numbers: 
\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
4 & 9 & 5 \\
\hline
7 & 3 & 8 \\
\hline
2 & 0 & 6 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
Below the grid, there are three circles labeled \( a, b, c \) for answers, and three additional circles labeled \( d, e, f \) for further answers.

The second grid also has three rows and three columns with the numbers:
\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
5 & 6 & 9 \\
\hline
1 & 2 & 7 \\
\hline
8 & 4 & 3 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
with similar answer circles below. 

[STRDGM] The first grid contains three rows and three columns with the numbers: 4, 9, 5 in the first row; 7, 3, 8 in the second row; and 2, 0, 6 in the third row. Below the grid, there are three circles labeled a, b, and c for answers, and three additional circles labeled d, e, and f for further answers. The second grid also has three rows and three columns with the numbers: 5, 6, 9 in the first row; 1, 2, 7 in the second row; and 8, 4, 3 in the third row, with similar answer circles below. [STPDGM]

\item Section (c) features a racquet and bills totaling \$17. 
\item Section (d) displays a radio and bills totaling \$28. 
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

Howard had $37 and he bought magazine racks that cost \( x \) dollars each. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the amount of money he had left in terms of \( x \).
\item If \( x = 4 \), find the amount of money he had left.
\item If \( x = 7 \), find the amount of money he had left.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing Howard with $37, 4 magazine racks, and the cost per rack labeled as \( x \). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Division Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

Joyce has \( y \) bananas. She eats 3 bananas and shares the remaining bananas equally among her 3 sisters. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the number of bananas each sister received in terms of \( y \).
\item If \( y = 9 \), find the number of bananas each sister received.
\item If \( y = 15 \), find the number of bananas each sister received.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting Joyce with \( y \) bananas, 3 bananas eaten, and 3 sisters receiving the remaining bananas equally. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

Three boys have stamps distributed as follows: Roland has \( z \) stamps, Peter has \( 2z \) stamps, and the third boy has \( 2 \times \) the number of stamps Peter has. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the total number of stamps the three boys have in terms of \( z \).
\item If \( z = 5 \), find the total number of stamps the three boys have.
\item If \( z = 9 \), find the total number of stamps the three boys have.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing Roland with \( z \) stamps, Peter with \( 2z \) stamps, and the third boy with \( 4z \) stamps. [STPDGM]

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\arabic*)]
\item \( 6 \text{ tens} - 5 \text{ tens} = \_\_\_ \text{ ten} \)  
\item \( 8 \text{ tens} - 1 \text{ ten} = \_\_\_ \text{ tens} \)  
\item \( 9 \text{ tens} - 6 \text{ tens} = \_\_\_ \text{ tens} \)  
\item \( 7 \text{ tens} - 3 \text{ tens} = \_\_\_ \text{ tens} \)  
\item \( 10 \text{ tens} - 8 \text{ tens} = \_\_\_ \text{ tens} \)  
\item \( 8 \text{ tens} - 3 \text{ tens} = \_\_\_ \text{ tens} \)  
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Addition Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Calculate the following addition problems:

\begin{enumerate}
\item \(10 + 3 = \)  
\item \(8 + 10 = \)  
\item \(6 + 10 = \)  
\item \(10 + 7 = \)  
\item \(10 + 2 = \)  
\item \(10 + 5 = \)  
\item \(4 + 10 = \)  
\item \(1 + 10 = \)  
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (Multi-part)

Solve the following arithmetic problems:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 2000 - 850 = \)
\item \( 950 + 50 = \)
\item \( 523 \times 7 = \)
\item \( 720 + 7 = \)
\item \( 400 + 2 = \)
\item \( 700 \times 2 = \)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Write ‘+’ or ‘-’ in each circle:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c}
10 & \circ & 4 = 6 \\
\hline
9 & \circ & 9 = 18 \\
\hline
9 & \circ & 6 = 15 \\
\hline
15 & \circ & 8 = 7 \\
\hline
16 & \circ & 6 = 10 \\
\hline
10 & \circ & 4 = 14 \\
\hline
8 & \circ & 8 = 0 \\
\hline
7 & \circ & 7 = 14 \\
\hline
12 & \circ & 9 = 3 \\
\hline
17 & \circ & 3 = 20 \\
\end{array}
\]

[STRDGM] A grid with numbers and circles where students need to determine if the operation is addition or subtraction based on the numbers provided. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (With Answer)

Adam paid 3 quarters and 1 nickel for a candy bar. How much did the candy bar cost? The candy bar cost __________ cents.

\subsection{Answers}
The candy bar cost 80 cents.

[STRDGM] A visual representation of a candy bar with coins labeled: 3 quarters (75 cents) and 1 nickel (5 cents), indicating the total cost of 80 cents. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (With Answer)

Juan has 54 marbles. He gives away 6 of them. How many marbles does he have left?

\subsection{Answers}
He has 48 marbles left.

[STRDGM] A diagram showing Juan with a total of 54 marbles and an arrow indicating 6 marbles being given away. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

Paul had 200 postcards. He lost 8 of them. What percentage of his postcards does he have left?

\subsection{Answers}
He has 96\% of his postcards left.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

There are 40 students in a class. 24 of them are boys. What percentage of the class are girls?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage of girls in the class is 40\%. 

[STRDGM] A classroom scene with 40 students, 24 boys on one side and 16 girls on the other side, illustrating the gender distribution. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

Rose and Mary shared 90 stickers. Rose received 27 stickers. What percentage of the stickers did Rose receive?

\subsection{Answers}
Rose received \( \frac{27}{90} \times 100 = 30\% \) of the stickers.

[STRDGM] A visual of two girls dividing a pile of 90 stickers, with 27 stickers highlighted for Rose. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

Jim and Tom have 400 picture cards altogether. If 220 picture cards belong to Jim, what percentage of the picture cards belong to Tom?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many picture cards belong to Tom?
\item What percentage of the total picture cards does Tom have?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] An image of two stacks of picture cards, one labeled Jim with 220 cards and the other labeled Tom with 180 cards. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

A baker made 600 buns. He sold 540 of them. What percentage of the buns did he have left?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage of buns left is 10\%.


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Eric has 60 green paper clips and 40 blue paper clips. What percentage of the paper clips are green?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage of green paper clips is \( \frac{60}{60 + 40} \times 100\% = 60\% \).


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Kelvin bought 8 Christmas greeting cards and 2 New Year greeting cards. What percentage of the greeting cards were Christmas greeting cards?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage of Christmas greeting cards is \( \frac{8}{10} \times 100\% = 80\% \).

[STRDGM] An arrangement of 10 greeting cards, with 8 Christmas cards and 2 New Year cards, showing the distribution. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

Lisa spent \$41 and had \$9 left. What percentage of her money did she spend?

\subsection{Answers}
The total amount of money Lisa had is \$41 + \$9 = \$50. The percentage spent is \(\frac{41}{50} \times 100 = 82\%\). 

[STRDGM] A visual of a wallet showing \$41 spent and \$9 remaining, illustrating the total amount of \$50. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer, Multi-part)

A factory employs 720 male workers and 280 female workers. What percentage of the workers are female?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage of female workers is \( \frac{280}{720 + 280} \times 100 = 28\% \). 

[STRDGM] A factory scene with two groups of workers, one group of 720 males and another group of 280 females, showing the gender ratio. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Jason collected 13 maps of Singapore and 7 maps of China. What percentage of his maps were of Singapore?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage of maps of Singapore is \( \frac{13}{13 + 7} \times 100\% = 65\% \).

[STRDGM] A visual of a collection of maps, with 13 maps labeled Singapore and 7 labeled China, illustrating the total collection. [STPDGM]

\subsection{Answers}

Jane and Cindy have 200 photographs altogether. Jane has 32 fewer photographs than Cindy. What percentage of the photographs are Jane's?

\subsection{Answers}
Jane has 84 photographs, which is 42\% of the total photographs.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Increase Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

The number of apple trees on a farm was increased by 40\%. The increase was 200 apple trees. Find the number of apple trees after the increase.

\subsection{Answers}
The number of apple trees after the increase is 700.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Decrease Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

The number of fishes in a large aquarium was decreased by 35\%. The decrease was 42 fishes. What was the number of fishes after the decrease?

\subsection{Answers}
The number of fishes after the decrease is 78.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Decrease Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

The number of motorcycles at a car park was decreased by 60\%. The decrease was 150 motorcycles. How many motorcycles were there after the decrease?

\subsection{Answers}
There were 100 motorcycles after the decrease. 

[STRDGM] A diagram of a car park with 250 motorcycles before the decrease and 100 motorcycles after the decrease, indicating a decrease of 150 motorcycles. [STPDGM]

\item The second section depicts three bags, each containing two round items. How many round items are there in total?
\item The third section illustrates two plates, each with three pear-like shapes. How many pear-like shapes are there in total?
\item The fourth section features four groups of two round objects with eyes. How many round objects with eyes are there in total?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The first section shows three hanging objects with 4 smaller items attached to each. The second section depicts three bags, each containing two round items. The third section illustrates two plates, each with three pear-like shapes. The fourth section features four groups of two round objects with eyes. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expression, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

(a) Express the total number of dolls Audrey has in terms of \( h \), where \( h \) represents the number of dolls on each shelf.  

(b) If \( h = 4 \), find the total number of dolls Audrey has.  

(c) If \( h = 6 \), find the total number of dolls Audrey has.  

[STRDGM] A diagram showing 7 shelves with \( h \) dolls on each shelf and a drawer labeled "36 dolls" to indicate the remaining dolls. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expression, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

(a) Express their total number of calendars in terms of \( i \).

(b) If \( i = 7 \), find their total number of calendars.

(c) If \( i = 12 \), find their total number of calendars.

\subsection{Answers}
(a) The total number of calendars is \( i + 3i = 4i \).

(b) If \( i = 7 \), the total number of calendars is \( 4 \times 7 = 28 \).

(c) If \( i = 12 \), the total number of calendars is \( 4 \times 12 = 48 \).

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating two people, Rachel with \( i \) calendars and Stella with \( 3i \) calendars, showing a comparison of their calendars. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expression, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

Sheila had a certain number of pencils. She gave \( j \) pencils to each of her 6 cousins and had 58 pencils left. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the original number of pencils Sheila had in terms of \( j \).
\item If \( j = 10 \), find the original number of pencils Sheila had.
\item If \( j = 16 \), find the original number of pencils Sheila had.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting Sheila giving \( j \) pencils to each of her 6 cousins, with a note indicating she had 58 pencils left. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Change Calculation) D 6 (With Illustration)

At a party, the number of men was decreased by 20\% to 160 and the number of women was increased by 10\% to 330. Find the overall increase or decrease in the number of people.

\subsection{Answers}
The overall change in the number of people is an increase of 10.

\item Calculate Mr. Simon's original salary before the increase.
\item Calculate Mrs. Simon's original salary before the decrease.
\item Determine the total salary before the changes and compare it to the total salary after the changes to find the overall increase or decrease.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{equation*}
7 + 6 = 13
\end{equation*}
\begin{equation*}

\end{equation*}

The first equation is correct as \( 7 + 6 = 13 \) and the second equation is also correct as \( 13 - 6 = 7 \).

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

There are 800 pens. 20\% of them are blue, 25\% of them are green, and 40\% of the remainder are black. The rest of the pens are red. How many red pens are there?

\subsection{Answers}
There are 320 red pens.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

There were 1400 people in a village in 1998. The number of people increased by 12\% in 1999 and later decreased by 25\% in 2000. How many fewer people were there in 2000 than in 1998?

\subsection{Answers}
There were 350 fewer people in 2000 than in 1998.

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

The usual selling prices of a handbag and a set of jewellery were \$990 and \$550 respectively. Jane bought them at a 10\% discount during a sale. How much did she pay altogether?

\subsection{Answers}
Jane paid \$1,386 altogether.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Sally wanted to buy a cordless phone and a printer that cost \$160 and \$380 respectively. If the salesman gave her a 15\% discount, how much discount did she get altogether?

\subsection{Answers}
The total discount is \$81.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

In 1999, 150 children were enrolled in Primary 1 at a certain school. The number of children enrolled increased by 20\% in 2000. In 2001, the number of children enrolled decreased by 20\%. How many children were enrolled in 2001?

\subsection{Answers}
The number of children enrolled in 2001 is 144.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

Jane had \$1200 savings in a bank. She withdrew some money yesterday and her savings decreased by 30\%. She withdrew some more money today and her savings decreased by 20\%. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How much money did Jane withdraw yesterday?
\item How much money did Jane withdraw today?
\item How much savings did she have left after both withdrawals?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A bank setting with a woman at a counter discussing her savings with a bank teller, with a calculator and withdrawal slips on the counter. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

A club had 5000 members in 1998. The number of club members decreased by 10\% in 1999. It increased by 30\% in 2000. How many more club members were there in 2000 than in 1998?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Calculate the number of members in 1999 after the decrease.
\item Calculate the number of members in 2000 after the increase.
\item Find the difference in the number of members between 2000 and 1998.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A club meeting room with members seated in a circle, discussing membership numbers, with a whiteboard showing the figures for 1998 (5000), 1999 (4500), and 2000 (5850). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (Multi-part)

Write the answers.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 20 + 1 \) 
\item \( 30 + 1 \) 
\item \( 20 - 1 \) 
\item \( 30 - 1 \) 
\item \( 33 + 2 \) 
\item \( 34 + 0 \) 
\item \( 35 - 2 \) 
\item \( 32 - 2 \) 
\item \( 36 + 3 \) 
\item \( 37 + 3 \) 
\item \( 39 - 3 \) 
\item \( 40 - 3 \) 
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Percentage Conversion Exercises, Multi-part) D 6 (With Answer)

1. Express \( \frac{17}{25} \) as a percentage.

2. Express \( \frac{5}{8} \) as a percentage.

3. Express 60% as a fraction in its simplest form.

4. Express 85% as a fraction in its simplest form.

5. Express 0.7 as a percentage.

6. Express 0.036 as a percentage.

7. Express 30% as a decimal.

8. Express 6% as a decimal.

9. Express 60 cents as a percentage of $3.

10. Express 18 cm as a percentage of 5 m.

11. Express 4.2 kg as a percentage of 2 kg.

12. Express 2 as a percentage of 800 ml.

\subsection{Answers}
1. 68\%
2. 62.5\%
3. \( \frac{3}{5} \)
4. \( \frac{17}{20} \)
5. 70\%
6. 3.6\%
7. 0.3
8. 0.06
9. 20\%
10. 360\%
11. 210\%
12. 0.25\%

(Mathematics) (Subtraction Exercise) D 1 (Multi-part)

Complete the following subtraction problems:

\begin{enumerate}
\item \(30 - 20 = 10\)
\item \(34 - 20 = \)
\item \(40 - 30 = \)
\item \(49 - 30 = \)
\item \(60 - 20 = \)
\item \(62 - 20 = \)
\item \(30 - 10 = \)
\item \(36 - 10 = \)
\item \(50 - 40 = \)
\item \(57 - 40 = \)
\item \(80 - 40 = \)
\item \(83 - 40 = \)
\item \(90 - 80 = \)
\item \(95 - 80 = \)
\end{enumerate}

The second section has a thought bubble with the equation \(34 - 20\), showing \(30\) and \(4\) as parts of the subtraction. The bottom section contains a grid with subtraction problems listed in a table format. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Average Calculation Exercise, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

(a) Express the average sum of money he spent each day in terms of \( n \).

(b) If \( n = 13 \), find the average sum of money he spent each day.

(c) If \( n = 25 \), find the average sum of money he spent each day.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Let \( S \) be the total sum of money spent over \( n \) days. The average sum spent each day can be expressed as \( \frac{S}{n} \).
\item If \( S = 169 \) (for example), then the average sum spent each day when \( n = 13 \) is \( \frac{169}{13} = 13 \).
\item If \( S = 250 \) (for example), then the average sum spent each day when \( n = 25 \) is \( \frac{250}{25} = 10 \).
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a boy with a stack of money, a calendar indicating 6 days, and arrows pointing to daily spending amounts. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

\item Express their total number of marbles in terms of \( p \).
\item If \( p = 42 \), find their total number of marbles.
\item If \( p = 64 \), find their total number of marbles.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting two boys, one with \( p \) marbles and the other with \( \frac{p}{2} \) marbles, with the total count displayed as \( p + \frac{p}{2} \). [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Division Exercise) D 3 (Multi-part)

Find the quotient and remainder for each of the following:

\begin{enumerate}[label=6)]
\item 92
\item 84
\item 78
\item 800
\item 605
\item 546
\item 496
\item 719
\item 923
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Nine boxes arranged in three rows of three, each labeled with "6)" followed by a number. Below each box, there are two lines labeled "Quotient:" and "Remainder:". [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Time-Telling Exercise, Fill in the Blank) D 3 (With Illustration)

What time is it? 

\begin{itemize}
\item 7:30
\item 5:24
\item Half past seven
\item 24 minutes past 5
\item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distance Comparison) D 3 (With Illustration)

Jim jogged 3 km 600 m. Mary jogged 2 km 800 m. Who jogged a longer distance? How much longer?

\subsection{Answers}
Jim jogged a longer distance of 800 m more than Mary.

[STRDGM] A diagram showing two people jogging, with Jim on one side labeled with "3 km 600 m" and Mary on the other side labeled with "2 km 800 m." An arrow pointing from Mary to Jim indicating the longer distance. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Cost Sharing Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

4 people bought a birthday present for their friend. They paid the cashier $100 and received $48 change. If they shared the cost equally, how much did each person pay?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Total Cost} = 100 - 48 = 52
\end{equation*}
\begin{equation*}
\text{Cost per Person} = \frac{52}{4}
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing four people around a table with a birthday present in the center, and a cash register displaying $100. An arrow pointing to a note showing $48 change. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Cik Faridah bought 8 packets of biscuits for a party. There were 12 biscuits in each packet. After the party, there were 28 biscuits left. How many biscuits were eaten at the party?

\subsection{Answers}
The number of biscuits eaten at the party is 64.

[STRDGM] A diagram showing 8 packets of biscuits with 12 biscuits in each, and a pile of biscuits with a label indicating "28 biscuits left" after the party. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Lily weighs 29 kg. Her father is 3 times as heavy as she. How much heavier is Lily’s father than Lily?

\subsection{Answers}
Lily’s father weighs 87 kg, which makes him 58 kg heavier than Lily.

[STRDGM] A scale showing Lily on one side weighing 29 kg and her father on the other side weighing 87 kg, indicating he is 3 times her weight. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Mr. Lin bought 2500 tiles. He used 1164 tiles for one room and 940 tiles for another room. How many tiles were left?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many tiles did Mr. Lin use in total?
\item How many tiles were left after using the tiles for both rooms?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual of a pile of 2500 tiles, with two smaller piles representing the used tiles (1164 and 940) being subtracted from the total. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Comparison Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

A factory has 2000 workers. 1340 of them are men. The rest are women. How many more men than women are there?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Number of women} = 2000 - 1340
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a total of 2000 workers, with 1340 labeled as men and 660 labeled as women, highlighting the difference in numbers. [STPDGM]

\subsection{Answers}
Samy has \$255. 

[STRDGM] A diagram showing Roy with \$85 and Samy with \$255, indicating that Samy's amount is three times Roy's. [STPDGM]

Gopal collected 48 postcards. He collected 4 times as many postcards as Raju. How many postcards did Raju collect?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Let } x \text{ be the number of postcards Raju collected. Then, } 4x = 48.
\end{equation*}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing Gopal with 48 postcards and Raju with 12 postcards, indicating Raju's amount is one-fourth of Gopal's. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

Mrs. Li bought 1 kg of flour. She used 450 g of it to bake a cake. How much flour does she have left?

\subsection{Answers}
She has 550 g of flour left. 

[STRDGM] A diagram showing 1 kg of flour with a portion of 450 g removed, indicating the remaining amount of 550 g. [STPDGM]

\item Three rectangles: the first has 3 out of 4 parts shaded, the second has 8 equal vertical sections with some shaded, and the third has 9 equal vertical sections with all shaded. Identify the fractions represented by each rectangle.
\item Three hexagons: the first is whole, the second is divided into 3 equal parts with 1 shaded, and the third is divided into 6 equal parts with all shaded. Identify the fractions represented by each hexagon.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Three circles, three rectangles, and three hexagons as described above. [STPDGM]

\subsection{Answers}

(Mathematics) (Write in Hours and Minutes Exercise) D 3 (With Answer)

Convert the following minutes into hours and minutes:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item 75 min 
\item 100 min 
\item 140 min 
\item 225 min 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
(a) 75 min = 1 h 15 min  
(b) 100 min = 1 h 40 min  
(c) 140 min = 2 h 20 min  
(d) 225 min = 3 h 45 min  

[STRDGM] A list format showing the conversion of total minutes into hours and minutes. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Word Problem) D 3 (Multi-part)

(a) At a zoo, the tigers are fed at 9:45 a.m. The lions are fed 40 minutes later. The lions are fed at __________.

(b) A concert started at 1:20 p.m. Alice and her friends arrived at the theatre at 12:50 p.m. They were __________ minutes early.

[STRDGM] Two sentences with blanks for time-related information, requiring calculations based on given times. The first involves adding 40 minutes to 9:45 a.m., and the second involves subtracting 12:50 p.m. from 1:20 p.m. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Time Addition Exercise) D 3 (Multi-part)

1. 
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \(1 \text{ h } 25 \text{ min} + 30 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(1 \text{ h } 45 \text{ min} + 40 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(2 \text{ h } 30 \text{ min} + 50 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(2 \text{ h } 35 \text{ min} + 35 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\end{enumerate}

2. 
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \(1 \text{ h } 50 \text{ min} + 2 \text{ h } 20 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(1 \text{ h } 45 \text{ min} + 1 \text{ h } 25 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(2 \text{ h } 20 \text{ min} + 1 \text{ h } 50 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(2 \text{ h } 40 \text{ min} + 1 \text{ h } 35 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(3 \text{ h } 50 \text{ min} + 1 \text{ h } 20 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\item \(3 \text{ h } 25 \text{ min} + 2 \text{ h } 45 \text{ min} = \_\_\_\_ \text{ h } \_\_\_\_ \text{ min}\)  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A girl with a ponytail is thinking, with a thought bubble showing the calculation: \(25 \text{ min} + 30 \text{ min} = 55 \text{ min}\). A boy is thinking, with a thought bubble showing the calculation: \(1 \text{ h } 50 \text{ min} + 2 \text{ h} = 3 \text{ h } 50 \text{ min} + 20 \text{ min} = 4 \text{ h } 10 \text{ min}\). [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise) D 3 (With Illustration)

Match the time durations with their equivalent days.

\begin{itemize}
    \item 1 week
    \item 2 weeks
    \item 3 weeks
    \item 4 weeks
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
    \item 7 days
    \item 14 days
    \item 21 days
    \item 28 days
\end{itemize}

[STRDGM] The image shows a matching exercise with arrows connecting time durations on the left (like "1 week" and "2 weeks") to circles on the right containing numbers of days (like "7 days" and "14 days"). The layout is structured with clear lines indicating the matches. [STPDGM]

\subsection{Answers}
Ahmad took 25 minutes longer than James.

(Mathematics) (Counting Exercise, Write Tens and Ones) D 1 (With Illustration)

Write the number of tens and ones in each section below:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item 
\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Tens} & \textbf{Ones} \\
\hline
5 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\item 
\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Tens} & \textbf{Ones} \\
\hline
5 & 3 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

\item 
\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Tens} & \textbf{Ones} \\
\hline
4 & 4 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Three sections for counting tens and ones: (1) shows five groups of ten circles (5 tens) and one individual circle (1 one). (2) shows five groups of ten (50) and three individual ones (3). (3) shows four groups of ten (40) and four individual ones (4). Each section has a table for writing the counts. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Fill in the blanks.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item There are ______ stickers altogether.
\item There are ______ stickers of swans.
\item There are ______ more stickers of owls than of parrots.
\item There are ______ fewer stickers of eagles than of swans.
\item The number of stickers of ______ is the greatest.
\item The number of stickers of ______ is the smallest.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A table with bird stickers represented by circles, showing different quantities for each bird: Owl, Peacock, Parrot, Swan, and Eagle. Each filled circle represents one sticker. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

The ratio of the number of James' marbles to the number of Mike's marbles was \( 2 : 9 \). Mike gave 60 of his marbles to James. How many marbles did James have in the end if he had \( \frac{5}{6} \) as many marbles as Mike?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Determine the initial number of marbles James and Mike had based on the given ratio.
\item Calculate how many marbles James had after receiving 60 marbles from Mike.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing two groups of marbles, one labeled "James" with an initial count of \( 2x \) and the other labeled "Mike" with an initial count of \( 9x \), with arrows indicating the transfer of 60 marbles from Mike to James. The final counts after the transfer should also be indicated. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

The ratio of the number of Ivy's bookmarks to the number of Sue's bookmarks was \( 8 : 7 \). Ivy gave \( \frac{1}{4} \) of her bookmarks to Sue. How many bookmarks did Ivy have at first if Sue had 48 more bookmarks than her finally?

\subsection{Answers}
Ivy had 56 bookmarks at first. 

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating two stacks of bookmarks, one for Ivy (56 bookmarks initially) and one for Sue (48 bookmarks more than Ivy after the transfer), with an arrow showing the transfer of \( \frac{1}{4} \) of Ivy's bookmarks to Sue. The initial and final counts are indicated, along with the ratio of bookmarks \( 8 : 7 \). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

The ratio of the number of Sam's postcards to the number of Alan's postcards was \( 11 : 4 \). After Sam gave 64 of his postcards to Alan, Sam had \( \frac{7}{8} \) as many postcards as Alan. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many postcards did Sam have initially?
\item How many postcards did Alan have initially?
\item How many postcards did Alan have in the end?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting two collections of postcards, one for Sam and one for Alan, with arrows showing the transfer of 64 postcards from Sam to Alan. The initial counts of postcards for Sam and Alan are marked, along with the ratio \( 11 : 4 \) and the final counts after the transfer. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

(a) Express the number of pies in each box in terms of \( y \), given that there are a total of 80 pies and some pies were burnt.

(b) If \( y = 8 \), find the number of pies in each box.

(c) If \( y = 14 \), find the number of pies in each box.

[STRDGM] A diagram showing 6 boxes with an equal number of pies in each, and a total of 80 pies, with some pies crossed out to indicate they were burnt. [STPDGM]

(c) If \( z = 25 \), find the number of music CDs Diana has more than Ashley.

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

Ivy has fewer beads than Jane. Let \( a \) represent the number of beads Ivy has fewer than Jane. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the number of beads Ivy has in terms of \( a \) if Jane has 30 beads.
\item If \( a = 2 \), find the number of beads Ivy has.
\item If \( a = 10 \), find the number of beads Ivy has.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing two people, Jane with 30 beads and Ivy with \( 30 - a \) beads, indicating the difference in the number of beads between them. [STPDGM]=

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\arabic*)]
\item \( 5 - 1 \) → [Answer]  
\item \( 7 - 2 \) → [Answer]  
\item \( 6 - 3 \) → [Answer]  
\item \( 10 - 4 \) → [Answer]  
\item \( 1 - 0 \) → [Answer]  
\end{enumerate}

(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

A farmer has 60 pigs and 75 goats. Find the ratio of the number of goats to the number of pigs.

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio of the number of goats to the number of pigs is \( \frac{75}{60} = \frac{5}{4} \).

[STRDGM] A farmer is in a field with 60 pigs and 75 goats, illustrating the comparison between the two animal counts. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

There are 24 boys and 16 girls in a class. Find the ratio of the number of boys to the total number of children.

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio of boys to the total number of children is \( \frac{24}{40} = \frac{3}{5} \).

[STRDGM] A classroom setting with 24 boys and 16 girls, showing the total number of students present. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

Edwin has 36 compact discs and 10 cassettes. Find the ratio of the number of cassettes to the total number of compact discs and cassettes.

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio of the number of cassettes to the total number of compact discs and cassettes is \( \frac{10}{46} \) or \( \frac{5}{23} \).


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Joshua weighs 54 kg and Mark weighs 45 kg. Find the ratio of Mark's weight to the total weight of the boys.

\begin{equation*}
\text{Total Weight} = \text{Joshua's Weight} + \text{Mark's Weight} = 54 \, \text{kg} + 45 \, \text{kg}
\end{equation*}

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio of Mark's weight to the total weight of the boys is \( \frac{45}{99} \) or \( \frac{5}{11} \).

[STRDGM] Two boys, Joshua and Mark, with their respective weights displayed (54 kg for Joshua and 45 kg for Mark), emphasizing the weight comparison. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Maggie is 144 cm tall and Stefan is 168 cm tall. Find the ratio of Stefan's height to the total height of Maggie and Stefan.

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio of Stefan's height to the total height of Maggie and Stefan is \( \frac{168}{144 + 168} = \frac{168}{312} = \frac{7}{13} \).

[STRDGM] Two individuals, Maggie and Stefan, standing side by side, with Maggie's height marked as 144 cm and Stefan's height marked as 168 cm. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Cynthia collected 65 flowers, Jane collected 50 flowers, and Irene collected 25 flowers. Find the ratio of the number of Cynthia's flowers to Jane's flowers and to Irene's flowers.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the ratio of Cynthia's flowers to Jane's flowers?
\item What is the ratio of Cynthia's flowers to Irene's flowers?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of Cynthia, Jane, and Irene with their respective flower counts: Cynthia with 65 flowers, Jane with 50 flowers, and Irene with 25 flowers. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Nancy has \$39, Daphne has \$27, and Wendy has \$54. Find the ratio of the amount of Nancy's money to the amount of Daphne's money to the amount of Wendy's money.

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio is \( 39:27:54 \) or simplified to \( 13:9:18 \).

[STRDGM] A visual representation showing Nancy with \$39, Daphne with \$27, and Wendy with \$54, with arrows indicating the ratios between their amounts. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

The capacities of three pails, A, B, and C, are 16 L, 20 L, and 18 L respectively. Find the ratio of the capacity of Pail A to the capacity of Pail B to the capacity of Pail C.

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio of the capacity of Pail A to Pail B to Pail C is \( \frac{16}{20} : \frac{16}{18} = 4 : 5 : 9 \).

[STRDGM] Three pails labeled A, B, and C, with capacities of 16 L, 20 L, and 18 L respectively, shown for comparison. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Desmond made 51 paper planes and Fabian made 33 paper planes. Find the ratio of the number of Desmond's paper planes to the number of Fabian's paper planes.

[STRDGM] Two individuals, Desmond and Fabian, each with their respective paper planes displayed: Desmond with 51 planes and Fabian with 33 planes, illustrating the comparison of their creations. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Ratio Problem, Word Problem) D 6 (With Answer)

There are 96 men and 72 women in a queue. Find the ratio of the number of men to the total number of men and women.

\subsection{Answers}
The ratio of the number of men to the total number of men and women is \( \frac{96}{96 + 72} = \frac{96}{168} = \frac{4}{7} \).

(Mathematics) (Word Problem) D 1 (With Answer)

After giving away 5 shells, John had 6 shells left. How many shells did he have at first?  

He had __________ shells at first.  

\subsection{Answers}  
He had 11 shells at first.

[STRDGM] A simple illustration of a boy with a thought bubble showing 11 shells, with a number line indicating the subtraction process where 11 - 5 = 6. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 1 (With Answer, Multi-part)

Nicole bought 12 pastries. She put 4 of them on a plate. She put the rest in a box. How many pastries were there in the box?  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many pastries did Nicole put in the box?
\item How many pastries did she buy in total?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
There were 8 pastries in the box.

Hazel has \( \frac{7}{10} \) as many coins as Victor. What is the ratio of the number of Hazel's coins to their total number of coins? __________

The ratio of the length of a rectangle to its breadth is \( 5:3 \). If its perimeter is \( 128 \, \text{cm} \), find its area. __________

[STRDGM] A rectangle labeled with its length and breadth, showing the ratio \( 5:3 \), with dimensions calculated as \( L = 5x \) and \( B = 3x \), and perimeter calculations illustrated as \( P = 2(L + B) = 128 \, \text{cm} \). [STPDGM]

\item If \( a = 18 \), find their total number of clocks.
\item If \( a = 24 \), find their total number of clocks.
\end{enumerate}

\item \( 100 - 50 = \)  
\end{enumerate}

Jasmine had \$100. She spent \$68. What percentage of her money did she spend? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What percentage of her money did Jasmine spend? 
\end{enumerate}

Vivian had 50 stamps. She used 14 stamps. What percentage of her stamps did she use? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What percentage of her stamps did Vivian use? 
\end{enumerate}

Victor had 80 marbles. He gave 40 marbles to his brother. What percentage of his marbles did he give to his brother? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What percentage of his marbles did Victor give to his brother? 
\end{enumerate}

June bought 25 storybooks. She read 12 of them. What percentage of her storybooks were not read? 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What percentage of her storybooks were not read? 
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The second section of the worksheet contains four word problems related to percentages, each with a blank line for answers. The problems involve financial transactions, usage of items, and reading statistics. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

The ratio of the number of pens in Box A to the number of pens in Box B was \( 3 : 7 \). After some pens from Box B were transferred to Box A, both boxes had 60 pens each. How many pens were transferred from Box B to Box A?

\begin{equation*}
\text{Let } x \text{ be the number of pens transferred from Box B to Box A.}
\end{equation*}

\subsection{Answers}
The number of pens transferred from Box B to Box A is 30. 

[STRDGM] Two boxes labeled A and B, with Box A initially having 30 pens and Box B having 70 pens. After transferring 30 pens, both boxes are shown to have 60 pens. [STPDGM]

[STRDGM] Two baskets labeled P and Q. Initially, Basket P has \( 8x \) eggs and Basket Q has \( 5x \) eggs, where \( x \) is a common multiplier. After transferring eggs, both baskets are shown to have 52 eggs each. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Cost Calculation Problems, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

Mary bought 3 identical blouses for \( s \) dollars. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the cost of each blouse in terms of \( s \).
\item If \( s = 12 \), find the cost of each blouse.
\item If \( s = 27 \), find the cost of each blouse.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting three identical blouses, each labeled with the cost variable \( \frac{s}{3} \), arranged in a row. The total cost is indicated as \( s \) dollars above the blouses. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Percentage Calculation, Word Problem) D 6 (With Illustration)

Kevin has 15 blue marbles, 25 green marbles, and 10 yellow marbles. What percentage of his marbles are yellow?

\subsection{Answers}
The percentage of yellow marbles is \( \frac{10}{50} \times 100\% = 20\% \).

[STRDGM] A collection of marbles: 15 blue, 25 green, and 10 yellow, totaling 50 marbles. The focus is on the yellow marbles to calculate their percentage. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 6 (With Answer)

John, Darren, and Paul shared 90 sweets. John got 24 sweets, Darren got 39 sweets, and Paul got the remaining sweets. What percentage of the sweets did Paul get?

\subsection{Answers}
Paul got 37 sweets, which is \( \frac{37}{90} \times 100 \approx 41.11\% \).

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Gilbert bought a watch for \$2800. Jack bought a similar watch at a 20\% discount. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How much did Jack pay for his watch?
\item How much less money did Jack pay than Gilbert?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A visual representation of two watches, one labeled with the price \$2800 and the other showing the calculation for a 20\% discount, which is \$560, leading to a final price of \$2240. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

Bernard bought a painting for \$3600. Lucas bought a similar painting that cost 35\% more than Bernard's painting. How much money did Lucas pay for his painting?

\subsection{Answers}
Lucas paid \$4860 for his painting.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Answer)

The total cost price of 50 teddy bears was \$150. They were sold at 80\% more than their cost price. Find the selling price of each teddy bear.

\subsection{Answers}
The selling price of each teddy bear is \$4.50. 

[STRDGM] A diagram illustrating 50 teddy bears with a total cost of \$150 and a calculation showing an 80\% markup on the cost price. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expression Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

4 boys have \( k \) kites each.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express their total number of kites in terms of \( k \).  
\item If \( k = 2 \), find their total number of kites.  
\item If \( k = 7 \), find their total number of kites.  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing 4 boys, each holding a kite, with a variable \( k \) representing the number of kites each boy has. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expression Exercise) D 6 (Multi-part)

There are 6 cages. There are \( m \) birds in each cage.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the total number of birds in terms of \( m \).
\item If \( m = 3 \), find the total number of birds.
\item If \( m = 5 \), find the total number of birds.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram depicting 6 cages, each containing a variable \( m \) number of birds, illustrating the relationship between the number of cages and birds. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Counting Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

Fill in the missing numbers.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Objects} & \text{Count} & \text{Missing Number} \\
\hline
\text{Rockets} & 3 & \_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Blocks} & 5 & \_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Triangles} & 2 & \_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Pencils} & 4 & \_\_ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

[STRDGM] The exercise consists of several rows with illustrations of objects (like rockets, blocks, triangles, and pencils) alongside numbers. Each row has a box for students to fill in the missing number based on the visual count of the objects. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

Match the items with their prices.

\begin{itemize}
    \item Bag A
    \item Bag B
    \item Bag C
    \item Bag D
\end{itemize}

Prices: 75¢, 95¢, 80¢, and 45¢.

[STRDGM] Four bags labeled A, B, C, and D, with coins inside, and price labels: 75¢, 95¢, 80¢, and 45¢. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Money Calculation Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

How much money is there in each set?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Bag (a) contains 5 quarters, 3 dimes, and 2 nickels. How much money is in bag (a)?
\item Bag (b) contains 10 pennies, 4 nickels, and 1 quarter. How much money is in bag (b)?
\item Bag (c) contains 2 stacks of dollar bills, each with 10 one-dollar bills. How much money is in bag (c)?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Three bags: (a) contains 5 quarters, 3 dimes, and 2 nickels; (b) contains 10 pennies, 4 nickels, and 1 quarter; (c) contains two stacks of dollar bills, each with 10 one-dollar bills. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Matching Exercise) D 1 (With Illustration)

Match the items with their prices.

[STRDGM] The image shows various items with corresponding prices. At the top, there is a teapot labeled \$8. Below it, there is a purse with several bills, followed by a fan labeled \$52. Next, there is another purse with bills and a calculator labeled \$32. Finally, there is a watch labeled \$45. Each item needs to be matched with the correct price. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

Henry had \( a \) stamps. He gave 3 stamps to his brother and 8 stamps to his sister.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the number of stamps Henry had left in terms of \( a \).  
\item If \( a = 26 \), find the number of stamps Henry had left.  
\item If \( a = 75 \), find the number of stamps Henry had left.  
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing Henry with a total of \( a \) stamps, with arrows indicating 3 stamps given to a brother and 8 stamps given to a sister, leading to the remaining stamps. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Algebraic Expressions, Word Problem) D 6 (Multi-part)

A baker had \( b \) cakes. He sold 9 cakes and made another 6 cakes. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Express the number of cakes he had in the end in terms of \( b \).
\item If \( b = 32 \), find the number of cakes he had in the end.
\item If \( b = 45 \), find the number of cakes he had in the end.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a baker with \( b \) cakes, with arrows indicating 9 cakes sold and 6 cakes made, leading to the final count of cakes. [STPDGM]

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item 4 fish, divide into 3 and 1.
\item 8 ladybugs, divide into 6 and 2.
\item 10 ice creams, divide into 5 and 5.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Three sets of objects: 4 fish, 8 ladybugs, and 10 ice creams, with lines indicating where to divide them into two parts. [STPDGM]

\item Draw to complete the set of hats.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Two sets of objects: cups and hats, with an incomplete set of 3 cups on the left and a blank space on the right for drawing the missing parts. The hats set has 2 hats on the left and a blank space on the right for drawing the missing parts. [STPDGM]

(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

500 tourists visited a museum last month. 15\% of them were Chinese, 35\% were Americans, and 20\% of the remainder were Japanese. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many Chinese tourists visited the museum?
\item How many Japanese tourists visited the museum?
\item How many more Chinese tourists than Japanese tourists were there?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing a total of 500 tourists, with sections for Chinese (75), American (175), and Japanese (50) tourists, illustrating the percentages and remaining tourists. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Distribution Exercise) D 6 (With Illustration, Multi-part)

Linda made 120 tarts. She gave \(10\%\) of them to her best friend, \(15\%\) of them to her neighbours, and \(40\%\) of the rest to her grandparents. How many tarts did she have left?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many tarts did Linda give to her best friend?
\item How many tarts did Linda give to her neighbours?
\item How many tarts did Linda give to her grandparents?
\item How many tarts does Linda have left?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A diagram showing the distribution of tarts: total tarts (120), portions given to the best friend (12), neighbours (18), and grandparents (remaining tarts calculated). [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Measurement Conversion, Fill in the Blank) D 5 (With Answer)

Find the equivalent measures.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.4 \) m = ________ cm
\item \( 1.25 \) kg = ______ kg ______ g 
\item \( 305 \) ml = ________ L
\item \( 0.75 \) ft = ________ in. 
\item \( 6.25 \) lb = _____ lb _____ oz 
\item \( 3.25 \) gal = ______ gal _____ c 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 40 \) cm 
\item \( 1 \) kg \( 250 \) g 
\item \( 0.305 \) L 
\item \( 9 \) in. 
\item \( 6 \) lb \( 4 \) oz 
\item \( 3 \) gal \( 4 \) c 
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Percentage Conversion, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Express each as a percentage. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.47 \) 
\item \( \frac{6}{15} \) 
\item \( 215 \) out of \( 500 \) 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 47\% \) 
\item \( 40\% \) 
\item \( 43\% \) 
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Percentage to Decimal and Fraction Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Express each percentage as a decimal and as a fraction in its simplest form.  

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 85\% \)  Decimal: _________  Fraction: __________ 
\item \( 16\% \)  Decimal: _________  Fraction: __________ 
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( 0.85 \), \( \frac{17}{20} \) 
\item \( 0.16 \), \( \frac{4}{25} \) 
\end{enumerate}


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

What is \( 32\% \) of \( \$96 \)?

\subsection{Answers}
The answer is \( \$30.72 \).


(Mathematics) (Average Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

Find the average of \( 21.4 \), \( 18.2 \), and \( 65.7 \). 

\subsection{Answers}
The average is \( 35.1 \).


(Mathematics) (Fill in the Blank, Average Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

Fill in the blank: The average of \( 42 \), \( 36 \), ______ , and \( 25 \) is \( 30 \).

\subsection{Answers}
The missing value is \( 17 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Percentage Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

John had \( \$75 \). He spent \( \$15 \) on a book. What percentage of his money does he have left?

\subsection{Answers}
He has \( 80\% \) of his money left.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Discount Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

The normal price of a camera was \( \$76 \). At a sale, it was sold at a discount of \( 15\% \). What was the selling price of the camera?

\subsection{Answers}
The selling price of the camera is \( \$64.60 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Average Weight Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

The average weight of \( 3 \) packages is \( 2 \) kg \( 750 \) g. The average weight of \( 2 \) of them is \( 3 \) kg \( 200 \) g. Find the weight of the third package. Give your answer in kg and g.

\subsection{Answers}
The weight of the third package is \( 1 \) kg \( 850 \) g.


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Arithmetic Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

In a city, the rate for taxi fare for the first kilometer is \( \$2.60 \) and for every additional kilometer it is \( \$0.80 \). Find the taxi fare for a journey of \( 6.5 \) km. 

\subsection{Answers}
The taxi fare is \( \$7.40 \).


(Mathematics) (Angle Calculation, Geometry Exercise) D 5 (With Answer)

The following figures are not drawn to scale. Find the unknown marked angle in each. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( ABC \) is a straight line. \( BCD \) is an equilateral triangle.
\item \( ABCD \) is a parallelogram.
\item \( ABC \) is a straight line. \( BCDE \) is a rhombus.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
(a) \( 85° \)

(b) \( 32° \)

(c) \( 65° \)

[STRDGM] Descriptions of diagrams:

- (a) A straight line \( ABC \) with \( BCD \) forming an equilateral triangle at point \( B \).

- (b) A parallelogram \( ABCD \).

- (c) A straight line \( ABC \) with \( BCDE \) forming a rhombus at point \( B \).

[STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation with Flow Rate) D 5 (With Answer)

A rectangular tank measures \( 50 \) cm by \( 20 \) cm by \( 33 \) cm. It is to be filled with water from a tap. It takes \( 2 \) minutes to fill it to a height of \( 12 \) cm. 

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item What is the rate of flow from the tap in liters per minute?
\item How many more minutes will it take to fill the tank?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Answers}
(a) \( 6 \) L/min

(b) \( 3.5 \) min

[STRDGM] A rectangular tank with dimensions \( 50 \) cm (length) \( \times \) \( 20 \) cm (width) \( \times \) \( 33 \) cm (height), filled to a height of \( 12 \) cm in \( 2 \) minutes. [STPDGM]


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation, Word Problem) D 5 (With Answer)

A rectangular container \( 8 \) cm long and \( 9 \) cm wide was filled with water to a depth of \( 6 \) cm. When \( 12 \) marbles of equal size were added to the container, the depth of the water became \( 7.5 \) cm. Find the volume of one marble.

\subsection{Answers}
The volume of one marble is \( 9 \text{cm}^3 \).


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation of Cubes) D 5 (With Answer)

How many \( 4 \)-cm cubes can fit into a rectangular box that is \( 1 \) m long, \( 0.4 \) m wide, and \( 0.6 \) m high?

\subsection{Answers}
The number of \( 4 \)-cm cubes that can fit into the box is \( 3750 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Money Distribution) D 5 (With Answer)

Sam had \( \$85 \) and John had \( \$220 \). They were each given an equal amount of money. After receiving the money, John had twice as much money as Sam. How much money did each boy receive?

\subsection{Answers}
Each boy received \( \$50 \).


(Mathematics) (Word Problem, Ratio Calculation) D 5 (With Answer)

Alice has \( 50\% \) of the amount of money Betty has, and Carrie has \( \frac{2}{5} \) of what Alice has. If Betty has \( \$364 \) more than Carrie, how much money does Alice have?

\subsection{Answers}
Alice has \( \$227.50 \).


(Mathematics) (Volume Calculation in Cubic Inches) D 5 (With Answer)

The length of one side of a cube is \( 1 \) \text{ft}. What is its volume in cubic inches?

\subsection{Answers}
The volume is \( 1728 \text{ in}^3 \).
